sentence.2847: title: Understanding DNS attacks: Identifying and patching vulnerabilities | Snyk url: https://snyk.io/blog/dns-attacks-identifying-patching-vulnerabilities/ The Domain Name System (DNS) translates domain names into IP addresses.
sentence.2848: Every device and website has an IP address that other devices, websites, and online services use to communicate with it.
sentence.2849: IP addresses are a string of numbers usually formatted as 000.000.000.000.
sentence.2850: However, we use domain names since people can’t easily remember these numbers.
sentence.2851: When we want to visit Google, we simply type the domain name into our browser’s address bar, and the DNS service translates the user-entered domain name “google.com” into the corresponding IP address that a computer uses.
sentence.2852: DNS is a fundamental component of the internet infrastructure, as any communication must start with a DNS name resolution.
sentence.2853: If the DNS becomes unavailable, internet programs will no longer function.
sentence.2854: DNS attacks refer to any attack that targets the stability and security of the DNS infrastructure.
sentence.2855: They commonly aim to render the DNS unavailable or intercept and alter the answers provided by the DNS, directing unsuspecting users to malicious websites.
sentence.2856: DNS infrastructure contains two components — authoritative and recursive DNS servers — and both are open to attack.
sentence.2857: Below, we’ll explore the most common attacks against DNS and review mitigation strategies to avoid them.
sentence.2858: Crash course in DNS attacksThere are several types of DNS attacks, each function differently, have unique impacts, and require specific countermeasures.
sentence.2859: SpoofingDNS spoofing occurs when threat actors alter the legitimate DNS server records to redirect users to fraudulent websites instead of their intended destination.
sentence.2860: When unsuspecting users reach the fraudulent website, the website prompts them to enter sensitive information, such as login details or credit card information.
sentence.2861: Threat actors use this technique to steal the victim’s sensitive data or plant malware — like ransomware or keyloggers — on their victim’s device.
sentence.2862: Attackers execute DNS spoofing attacks using two methods:Intercepting the communications between the target device and the DNS server and redirecting users’ requests to a malicious websiteDirectly attacking the legitimate DNS server and forcing it to return malicious IP addressesTo counter this attack, we should:Update and patch the DNS server software regularly.
sentence.2863: Check the website for the secure connection (padlock) symbol.
sentence.2864: This symbol appears next to the address bar of the web browser.
sentence.2865: If there’s no padlock, this may indicate threat actors have mirrored the website for malicious purposes.
sentence.2866: Enable the Domain Name System Security Extensions (DNSSEC) on the domain.
sentence.2867: These extensions add a layer of security by attaching a digital certificate signature to DNS information.
sentence.2868: Cache poisoningIn this attack, the threat actor injects false DNS information into the DNS cache to force it to return incorrect information and direct users to malicious websites.
sentence.2869: For example, when a user requests to visit google.com, the poisoned DNS server returns the IP address of another website that could contain an exploit kit or phishing page.
sentence.2870: DNS cache poisoning and spoofing are often used interchangeably in cybersecurity.
sentence.2871: However, they are different in terms of their function and order of appearance.
sentence.2872: In DNS poisoning, threat actors replace the DNS records to redirect unsuspecting users to malicious destinations.
sentence.2873: Then, DNS spoofing redirects unsuspecting users to the malicious website using a poisoned cache.
sentence.2874: To prevent a DNS poisoning attack, we should:Use DNSSEC, which uses public key cryptography.
sentence.2875: This ensures that only a legitimate DNS nameserver answers a request with the correct DNS information.
sentence.2876: Prevent local DNS servers from answering internet-based DNS queries — unless our DNS nameserver is registered with ICANN.DoS/DDoS/floodingDNS flooding is an attack by which malicious actors try to overwhelm DNS servers with false DNS requests to prevent them from serving legitimate requests.
sentence.2877: There are two types of DNS flood attacks: denial of service (DoS) flooding and distributed denial of service (DDoS) flooding.
sentence.2878: DoS flood attackIn a DoS flood attack, the attacker uses one computer to flood a remote DNS server with false traffic.
sentence.2879: This technique is no longer effective because modern DNS servers have advanced technical specifications that one device cannot disrupt.
sentence.2880: DDoS DNS flood attackThe DDoS DNS flood is the most effective attack mechanism wherein attackers use many devices to target one DNS server.
sentence.2881: This action consumes the target DNS memory and CPU resources, eventually taking the server offline.
sentence.2882: In cybersecurity, a bot can refer to any computing device, for example, a laptop, workstation, or internet of things (IoT) device infected with malware and under a threat actor’s control.
sentence.2883: A collection of these bots is called a botnet.
sentence.2884: Attackers commonly use networks of botnets containing thousands or millions of compromised devices that run malicious scripts.
sentence.2885: The attacker orchestrates the attack by directing all devices to send traffic simultaneously to one server, generating a DoS status.
sentence.2886: DNS floods are considered relatively modern, made widely possible by the increasing numbers of IoT devices worldwide.
sentence.2887: Many IoT devices have poor security configurations, making them easy targets for hackers to control.
sentence.2888: To prevent DDoS and DoS flood attacks, we should:Use a DDoS mitigation service to prevent outside attackers from overwhelming our DNS servers with false requests.
sentence.2889: Use one dedicated server as the authoritative name server and another as the DNS resolver.
sentence.2890: This enables one component to remain operational if the second fails.
sentence.2892: Small and medium-sized organizations often use one server for multiple purposes, such as hosting applications and running the DNS service.
sentence.2893: However, if the attacker accesses one application hosted on the server, they can compromise and alter the DNS settings.
sentence.2894: NXDomainLike a DNS flood attack, the NXDomain attack overwhelms the target DNS server with many requests for invalid records (nonexistent domain names).
sentence.2895: To execute this attack, attackers use a DNS proxy server that automatically sends a massive number of DNS requests to the targeted authoritative DNS server.
sentence.2896: The authoritative server consumes resources (fills the server cache) in resolving these invalid requests, making it respond slowly to legitimate requests — and eventually stop responding altogether.
sentence.2897: To prevent the DNS NXD flood attack, we should:Conduct regular DNS audits.
sentence.2898: Blocklist suspicious domain names and servers.
sentence.2899: Temporarily blocklist a client’s IP address if it sends too many NXDomain requests.
sentence.2900: Increase the Time to Live (TTL) on current DNS records to ensure that they’ll remain for an extended time in external DNS caches.
sentence.2901: These records don’t need to be updated regularly.
sentence.2902: Amplification attacksThis is another DDoS attack that aims to prevent the target DNS server from serving legitimate DNS queries.
sentence.2903: In this attack, threat actors exploit open DNS servers to send multiple responses to the target server.
sentence.2904: Threat actors initiate this attack by sending numerous DNS requests to the open DNS server using the target IP address as the source address.
sentence.2905: The open DNS server returns the response to the requester (in this example, the target spoofed IP address).
sentence.2906: Sending many DNS responses eventually crashes the target server by consuming its network bandwidth and making it unresponsive to legitimate requests.
sentence.2907: Attackers commonly leverage botnets, especially on IoT devices, to generate spoofed DNS requests to overwhelm the target servers or organization network with DNS responses.
sentence.2908: To prevent this attack, we should:Enforce source IP verifications on all network devices.
sentence.2909: Prevent DNS authoritative name servers from functioning as recursive servers.
sentence.2910: Enforce response rate limiting (RRL) settings on all DNS servers.
sentence.2911: Configure open DNS resolvers to only respond to queries from a trusted source.
sentence.2912: HijackingIn this attack, threat actors manipulate DNS response queries to direct unsuspecting users to fraudulent or malicious websites.
sentence.2913: This attack occurs by:Installing malware, such as a trojan horse, on the victim’s computer to incorrectly resolve DNS queries and lead the unsuspecting user to malicious sitesCompromising the target router and changing its DNS settings.
sentence.2914: This affects all users connected to the router.
sentence.2915: Intercepting the communications between the legitimate DNS server and user device — as in the case of a man-in-the-middle attack — and manipulating DNS responses to lead the unsuspecting user to malicious sitesTargeting the DNS server directly and then changing its DNS settings to lead unsuspecting users to different URLsAlthough
sentence.2916: this attack is malicious, some internet service providers (ISPs) use this technique to direct users to other websites.
sentence.2917: For example, some ISPs use it to display advertisements based on a user’s browsing history.
sentence.2918: RebindingIn this attack, the threat actor infects the target router with malware to control it remotely.
sentence.2919: The attack begins by executing malicious JavaScript code on a user’s browser to infect the router.
sentence.2920: Many people don’t protect their router using a complex password — or just safeguard it using the default factory credentials.
sentence.2921: This leaves them vulnerable to rebinding attacks.
sentence.2922: A good first step toward guarding against rebinding attacks is to protect the router with a strong password.
sentence.2923: We should also:Change the default router username and password to something difficult to guess.
sentence.2924: Keep the DNS server and all client operating systems and installed applications up to date.
sentence.2925: Tunneling This DNS attack routes unsuspecting user traffic to the attacker’s server.
sentence.2926: This attack is typical among ransomware operators for facilitating communication with the Command and Control Center (C&C) and exfiltrating data from the target device.
sentence.2927: DNS tunneling evades detection by security tools like firewalls.
sentence.2928: Threat actors send stolen data from the target network in small chunks and deliver them as a series of DNS queries and responses to avoid detection.
sentence.2929: A DNS tunneling attack works as follows:The attacker has a server with a domain name pointing to it.
sentence.2931: The attacker infects a computer with malware.
sentence.2932: The infected computer might sit behind a company firewall but can use the DNS resolver.
sentence.2933: Now, the DNS resolver can communicate with the remote attacker’s C&C server.
sentence.2934: By doing this, each infected device and the remote attacker’s server have created a covert channel that can be used to exfiltrate data from the victim device or deliver more malware, such as ransomware, to the target device.
sentence.2935: To prevent this attack, we should:Use advanced security solutions, including next-generation firewalls on network perimeters and network detection and response (NDR), to monitor all interactions within our IT environment.
sentence.2936: This enables us to detect APT and ransomware operators and halt communications with attackers’ servers.
sentence.2937: Configure all devices within an organization’s network to send all their DNS queries to an internal DNS server that blocks suspicious domain names.
sentence.2938: Phantom domainIn this attack, the threat actor sets up numerous phantom domain names and requests the target DNS server to resolve them.
sentence.2939: These domains (commonly a large number of sub-domain names) respond very slowly or never.
sentence.2940: After a while, the target DNS server consumes its server cache while waiting for the attacker domain’s responses and eventually becomes unresponsive.
sentence.2941: To prevent this attack, we should:Increase the number of recursive DNS servers.
sentence.2942: Limit the number of successive recursive DNS requests on each DNS server.
sentence.2943: ConclusionThe DNS service is a critical component of internet infrastructure.
sentence.2944: It’s responsible for translating users’ domain names into IP addresses that other servers can understand.
sentence.2945: However, it was not made for security.
sentence.2946: With the widespread use of the internet and the growing number of cyberattacks, cybercriminals have become increasingly interested in DNS attacks.
sentence.2947: Any attack against the DNS service prevents all internet programs from functioning correctly.
sentence.2948: Cybercriminals know this and have developed many ways to attack DNS services for malicious purposes.
sentence.2949: There are several different techniques to attack the DNS service, which we can group into two main categories:Attacks that aim to make the DNS service unavailableAttacks that aim to manipulate the DNS records to lead unaware users to malicious destinationsAs this article has demonstrated, each type of DNS attack requires a different set of countermeasures to mitigate it.
sentence.2950: However, generally speaking, the keys to preventing DNS attacks include keeping the DNC server software up to date, using a dedicated DNS server to provide the DNS service, increasing the number of recursive DNS servers, and checking for vulnerabilities to mitigate DDoS attacks.
sentence.2951: title: EvilExtractor – All-in-One Stealer url: https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/evil-extractor-all-in-one-stealer Affected platforms: WindowsImpacted parties: Any organizationImpact: Controls victim’s device and collects sensitive informationSeverity level: Critical EvilExtractor (sometimes spelled Evil Extractor) is an attack tool designed to target Windows operating systems and extract data and files from endpoint devices.
sentence.2952: It includes several modules that all work via an FTP service.
sentence.2953: It was developed by a company named Kodex, which claims it is an educational tool.
sentence.2954: However, research conducted by FortiGuard Labs shows cybercriminals are actively using it as an info stealer.
sentence.2955: Based on our traffic source data to the host, evilextractor[.]com, malicious activity increased significantly in March 2023.
sentence.2956: FortiGuard Labs observed this malware in a phishing email campaign on 30 March, which we traced back to the samples included in this blog.
sentence.2957: It usually pretends to be a legitimate file, such as an Adobe PDF or Dropbox file, but once loaded, it begins to leverage PowerShell malicious activities.
sentence.2958: It also contains environment checking and Anti-VM functions.
sentence.2959: Its primary purpose seems to be to steal browser data and information from compromised endpoints and then upload it to the attacker’s FTP server.
sentence.2960: We recently reviewed a version of the malware that was injected into a victim’s system and, as part of that analysis, identified that most of its victims are located in Europe and America.
sentence.2961: The developer released its project in October 2022 (Figure 1) and has kept updating it to increase its stability and strengthen its module.
sentence.2962: This article will examine the initial attack method used to deliver EvilExtractor and its functions. Figure 1.
sentence.2963: EvilExtractor for sale on the web Initial Access The phishing email with the malicious attachment is shown in Figure 2.
sentence.2964: It is disguised as an account confirmation request.
sentence.2965: The attacker also tricks the victim by using an Adobe PDF icon for the decompressed file.
sentence.2966: The PE header is shown in Figure 3.
sentence.2969: File header of "Account_Info.exe" The execution file is a Python program packaged by PyInstaller.
sentence.2970: We extracted it with pyinstxtractor and found that the “PYARMOR” string in its main code file “contain.pyc”, shown in Figure 4, is an obfuscating tool for Python script that makes the malware harder to be analyzed and detected.
sentence.2971: We extracted the key and iv from _pytransform.dll and decrypted the “contain.pyc” using AES-GCM. Figure 4.
sentence.2973: In addition to the Python program, we observed a .NET loader that can extract EvilExtractor.
sentence.2974: Figure 5 is part of the code.
sentence.2975: It contains Base64-encoded data, which is a PowerShell script.
sentence.2976: This execution file is generated from the tool “PS2EXE-GUI”, which can convert PowerShell scripts to EXE Files.
sentence.2978: Code for EvilExtractor EvilExtractor After decrypting the pyc file, we get the primary code of EvilExtractor.
sentence.2979: It is a PowerShell script that contains the following modules:
sentence.2980: Date time checking Anti-Sandbox Anti-VM Anti-Scanner FTP server setting Steal data Upload Stolen data Clear log It first checks whether the system’s date is between 2022-11-09 and 2023-04-12.
sentence.2981: If not, it uses the following command to delete the data in PSReadline and terminate: DEL \"$env:APPDATA\Microsoft\Windows\PowerShell\PSReadline\*\" -Force –Recurse It then compares the product model to see if it matches any of the following: VirtualBox, VMWare, Hyper-V, Parallels, Oracle VM VirtualBox, Citrix Hypervisor, QEMU, KVM, Proxmox VE, or Docker, as shown in Figure 6.
sentence.2982: It also checks the victim’s hostname against 187 names from VirusTotal machines or other scanner/virtual machines, as shown in Figure 7. Figure 6.
sentence.2983: EvilExtractor comparing product model for match Figure 7.
sentence.2984: Virtual environment and scanner/virtual machine checking After passing the environment check, EvilExtractor downloads three components from http://193[.]42[.]33[.]232 used for stealing data.
sentence.2985: These files are also Python programs that are obfuscated using PyArmor.
sentence.2986: The first is “KK2023.zip”, which is used for stealing browser data and saving it in the folder “IMP_Data”.
sentence.2987: It can extract cookies from Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Opera, and Firefox.
sentence.2988: It also collects browser history and passwords from the following browsers: The second file is “Confirm.zip”.
sentence.2989: It is a key logger that saves data in the “KeyLogs” folder.
sentence.2990: The last file, “MnMs.zip”, is a webcam extractor.
sentence.2991: Its corresponding code is shown in Figure 8. Figure 8.
sentence.2992: Download components for the Keylogger and Webcam Snapshot functions EvilExtractor also collects system information by PowerShell script, shown in Figure 9.
sentence.2993: Figure 10 shows the concatenated data in a text file called “Credentials.txt”.
sentence.2995: PowerShell script for collecting system information Figure 10.
sentence.2996: Content of “Credentials.txt” EvilExtractor downloads files with specific extensions from the Desktop and Download folders, including jpg, png, jpeg, mp4, mpeg, mp3, avi, txt, rtf, xlsx, docx, pptx, pdf, rar, zip, 7z, csv, xml, and html.
sentence.2997: It also uses the command “CopyFromScreen” to capture a screenshot.
sentence.2998: The code is shown in Figure 11. Figure 11.
sentence.2999: Downloading files and getting a screenshot After EvilExtractor extracts all the data from the compromised endpoint, it uploads it to the attacker’s FTP server, shown in Figure 12.
sentence.3000: The developer of EvilExtractor also provides an FTP server for those who purchase its malware. Figure 12.
sentence.3002: FTP server Kodex Ransomware EvilExtractor also has a ransomware function.
sentence.3003: It is called “Kodex Ransomware”, as shown in Figure 13.
sentence.3004: We extracted this PowerShell script from the .Net loader mentioned in the previous section, and the script for its ransomware is similar to the one for its stealer.
sentence.3006: Introduction form evilextracom[.]com It downloads “zzyy.zip” from evilextractor[.]com.
sentence.3007: Details of the unzipped file, a 7-zip standalone console, are shown in Figure 14.
sentence.3008: Figure 15 shows it leverages “7za.exe” to encrypt files with the parameter “-p”, which means zipping files with a password.
sentence.3009: It also generates a ransom-demanding message saved in “KodexRansom”, shown in Figure 16. Figure 14.
sentence.3011: PowerShell script for Kodex Ransomware Figure 16.
sentence.3012: Kodex ransomware's note Conclusion EvilExtractor is being used as a comprehensive info stealer with multiple malicious features, including ransomware.
sentence.3013: Its PowerShell script can elude detection in a .NET loader or PyArmor.
sentence.3014: Within a very short time, its developer has updated several functions and increased its stability.
sentence.3015: This blog explains how threat actors launch an attack via phishing mail and what files are leveraged to extract the EvilExtracrtor PowerShell script.
sentence.3016: We also detailed what functions are included, what data can be collected by EvilExtractor, and how the Kodex Ransomware works.
sentence.3017: Users should be aware of this new info stealer and continue to be cautious about suspicious mail.
sentence.3020: The malware described in this report are detected and blocked by FortiGuard Antivirus as: W32/EvilExtractor.
sentence.3023: A!tr The FortiGuard AntiVirus service is supported by FortiGate, FortiMail, FortiClient, and FortiEDR, and the Fortinet AntiVirus engine is a part of each of those solutions.
sentence.3024: Customers running current AntiVirus updates are protected.
sentence.3025: The FortiGuard Web Filtering Service blocks the malicious URL and IP address.
sentence.3026: If you think this or any other cybersecurity threat has impacted your organization, contact our Global FortiGuard Incident Response Team.
sentence.3028: title: LockBit 2.0: How This RaaS Operates and How to Protect Against It url: https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/lockbit-2-ransomware/ Executive Summary LockBit 2.0 is ransomware as a service (RaaS) that first emerged in June 2021 as an upgrade to its predecessor LockBit (aka ABCD Ransomware), which was first observed in September 2019.
sentence.3029: Since its inception, the LockBit 2.0 RaaS attracted affiliates via recruitment campaigns in underground forums, and thus became particularly prolific during the third quarter of calendar year 2021.
sentence.3030: The LockBit 2.0 operators claimed to have the fastest encryption software of any active ransomware strain as of June 2021, claiming accordingly that this added to its effectiveness and ability to disrupt the ransomware landscape.
sentence.3031: While several top-tier RaaS affiliate programs, such as Babuk, DarkSide and REvil (aka Sodinokibi) disappeared from the underground in 2021, LockBit 2.0 continued to operate and gradually became one of the most active ransomware operations.
sentence.3032: While Conti was recognized as being the most prolific ransomware deployed in 2021 per our 2022 Unit 42 Ransomware Threat Report, LockBit 2.0 is the most impactful and widely deployed ransomware variant we have observed in all ransomware breaches during the first quarter of 2022, considering both leak site data and data from cases handled by Unit 42 incident responders.
sentence.3033: According to data analysis of ransomware groups’ dark web leak sites, LockBit 2.0 was the most impactful RaaS for five consecutive months.
sentence.3034: As of May 25, LockBit 2.0 accounted for 46% of all ransomware-related breach events for 2022.
sentence.3035: And the LockBit 2.0 RaaS leak site has the most significant number of published victims, with over 850 in total.
sentence.3036: Additionally, LockBit 2.0 has affected many companies globally, with top victims based in the U.S., Italy and Germany.
sentence.3037: Its most highly targeted industry verticals include professional services, construction, wholesale and retail, and manufacturing.
sentence.3038: Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections against LockBit 2.0 attacks from Cortex XDR, as well as from the WildFire cloud-delivered security subscription for the Next-Generation Firewall.
sentence.3039: (Please see the Conclusion section for more detail.)
sentence.3040: Table of Contents LockBit 2.0 OverviewVictimologyLeak Site DataUnit 42 Incident Response Data on LockBit 2.0LockBit 2.0 Tactics, Techniques and ProceduresLockBit 2.0 Technical DetailsLockBit 3.0Courses of ActionConclusionAppendix AAdditional Resources LockBit 2.0 Overview LockBit 2.0 is another example of RaaS that leverages double extortion techniques as part of the attack to pressure victims into paying the ransom.
sentence.3041: In some cases, LockBit 2.0 operators have performed DDoS attacks on the victims' infrastructure as well as using a leak site.
sentence.3042: This practice is known as triple extortion, a tactic observed in groups like BlackCat, Avaddon and SunCrypt in the past.
sentence.3043: Like other ransomware families such as BlackByte, LockBit 2.0 avoids systems that use Eastern European languages, including many written with Cyrillic alphabets.
sentence.3044: Unlike other RaaS programs that don't require the affiliates to be super technical or savvy, LockBit 2.0 operators allegedly only work with experienced penetration testers, especially those experienced with tools like Metasploit and Cobalt Strike.
sentence.3045: Affiliates are tasked with gaining initial access to the victim network, allowing LockBit 2.0 to conduct the rest of the attack.
sentence.3046: LockBit 2.0 has been observed changing infected computers’ backgrounds to a ransomware note.
sentence.3047: The ransomware note was also used to recruit insiders from victim organizations.
sentence.3048: The notes claimed the threat actors would pay “millions of dollars” to insiders who provided access to corporate networks or facilitated a ransomware infection by opening a phishing email and/or launching a payload manually.
sentence.3049: The threat actors also expressed interest in other access methods such as RDP, VPN and corporate email credentials.
sentence.3050: In exchange, they offer a cut of the paid ransom.
sentence.3052: The operators work with initial access brokers to save time and allow for a larger profit potential.
sentence.3053: While typically seeking victims of opportunity, LockBit 2.0 does appear to have victim limitations.
sentence.3054: The group announced that they would not target healthcare facilities, social services, educational institutions, charitable organizations and other organizations that “contribute to the survival of the human race”.
sentence.3055: However, despite these claims, there have been instances of affiliates undermining these guidelines by still opting to attack industry verticals such as healthcare and education.
sentence.3056: Organizations in Europe and the U.S. are hit more often by LockBit 2.0 than those in other countries, likely due to the high profitability and insurance payouts.
sentence.3057: Leak Site Data During the first calendar year quarter of 2022, LockBit 2.0 persisted as the most impactful and the most deployed ransomware variant we observed in all ransomware breaches shared on leak sites.
sentence.3059: Ransomware leak site data from the first calendar year quarter of 2022.According to leak site data analysis, LockBit 2.0 was the most impactful RaaS for five consecutive months.
sentence.3060: As of May 25, LockBit 2.0 accounted for 46% of all ransomware-related breach events for 2022 shared on leak sites.
sentence.3061: Additionally, the LockBit 2.0 RaaS leak site has the most significant number of published victims, with over 850 in total.
sentence.3062: The site itself typically features information such as victim domains, a time tracker and measures of how much data was compromised. Figure 2.
sentence.3064: LockBit 2.0 claims that they have demanded ransom from at least 12,125 companies, as shown in the figure below.
sentence.3067: According to leak site data for LockBit 2.0, since its inception in June 2021, the RaaS has affected many companies globally, with top victims based in the U.S., Italy and Germany. Figure 4.
sentence.3069: LockBit 2.0 has also impacted various victims across multiple industry verticals.
sentence.3070: Its most highly targeted industry verticals include professional services, construction, wholesale and retail and manufacturing. Figure 5.
sentence.3072: When looking at leak site data across all ransomware families, we’ve observed LockBit 2.0 targeting the highest number of organizations in the following regions: JAPAC, EMEA, and LATAM.
sentence.3073: Unit 42 Incident Response Data on LockBit 2.0 Cases handled by Unit 42 security consultants involving LockBit 2.0 since its appearance in June 2021 demonstrate shorter dwell times and less flexibility in negotiation in the beginning of FY 2022 (measured October-September) in comparison to the end of FY 2021.
sentence.3074: The following data is broken into fiscal years and quarters based on when the threat actor breached the network, not when the activity was noticed by a client.
sentence.3075: LockBit 2.0 has shown a decrease in dwell time in FY 2022.
sentence.3076: From the last two quarters of FY 2021 to the first two quarters of FY 2022, there has been an average 37-day difference.
sentence.3078: LockBit 2.0 average dwell time by fiscal quarter.
sentence.3079: The difference in initial and final ransom demands over the past fiscal year has been converted to percentages and then averaged.
sentence.3080: The graph below demonstrates that at the end of FY 2021, threat actors using LockBit 2.0 were much more open to negotiations of ransom amounts; during that time the ransom was dropped approximately 83% from the initial ask on average.
sentence.3081: In comparison, we see less flexibility in FY 2022 Q1 and Q3 – threat actors only offered an average of about 30% as a price drop.
sentence.3082: FY 2022 Q2 is not included due to lack of sufficient information.
sentence.3084: LockBit 2.0 average difference in initial vs final ransom amount, shown as percentages.
sentence.3085: LockBit 2.0 Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Technically speaking, we have observed LockBit 2.0 affiliates leveraging the following tactics, techniques and procedures: TA0001 Initial Access T1078 Valid Accounts Credentials that have either been reused across multiple platforms or have previously been exposed.
sentence.3086: Additionally, this includes VPN accounts – not just domain and local accounts.
sentence.3088: External Remote Services Affiliates have been seen brute forcing exposed RDP services and compromising accounts with weak passwords.
sentence.3089: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Applications Vulnerabilities such as ProxyShell (CVE-2021-34473) and improper SQL sanitization (CVE-2021-20028)
sentence.3090: have been observed being utilized as footholds into the environment.
sentence.3091: TA0002 Execution T1053.005 Scheduled Task/Job Scheduled Task.
sentence.3092: LockBit 2.0 can be executed via scheduled tasks.
sentence.3094: Command and Scripting Interpreter LockBit 2.0 is typically executed via command line arguments via a hidden window.
sentence.3095: Windows SysInternals PsExec has been utilized for both persistence and execution purposes.
sentence.3096: Its ability to execute processes on other systems spread the ransomware and assisted in reconnaissance activities.
sentence.3097: TA0003 Persistence T1053.005 Scheduled Task/Job Scheduled Task.
sentence.3098: It was quite common to see scheduled tasks used to create persistence for the ransomware executable, PsExec, and occasionally some defense evasion batch scripts.
sentence.3100: Valid Accounts Compromised accounts may be used to maintain access to the network.
sentence.3103: In rare cases, LockBit 2.0 has been observed to create accounts for persistence with simple names, such as “a.” T1505.003 Server Software Component With the upsurgence of ProxyShell, webshells have become more common entry points.
sentence.3104: TA0004 Privilege Escalation T1068 Exploitation for Privilege Escalation The ProxyShell elevation of privilege on the Exchange PowerShell Backend (CVE-2021-34523), Windows Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS) improperly handling symbolic links (CVE-2020-0787), and abusing the CMSTPLUA COM interface have all been seen as methods of privilege escalation.
sentence.3105: T1548.002 Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism: Bypass User Account Control LockBit 2.0 has utilized a UAC bypass tool.
sentence.3106: TA0005 Defense Evasion T1070 Indicator Removal on Host Indicators, such as logs in Windows Event Logs or malicious files, are typically removed using wevtutil, a batch script, or CCleaner.
sentence.3107: T1140 Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information Most PowerShell scripts involved in LockBit 2.0 cases are Base64 encoded.
sentence.3109: Group Policy Modification LockBit 2.0 has been seen using the PowerShell module InvokeGPUpdate to update the group policy.
sentence.3111: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools Windows Defender, other anti-malware solutions and monitoring tools are disabled utilizing a process explorer tool, a batch script or a specially crafted command line script.
sentence.3113: Hide Artifacts: Hidden Window Affiliates use hidden windows to hide malicious activity from plain sight.
sentence.3114: TA0006 Credential Access T1003 OS Credential Dumping As seen with other ransomware cases, Mimikatz is a key player in dumping credentials but LockBit 2.0 has been occasionally seen utilizing MiniDump as well.
sentence.3115: T1555 Credentials from Password Stores LockBit 2.0 has been seen utilizing numerous tools to dump passwords from password stores and Chrome using GrabChrome and GrabRFF.
sentence.3116: TA0007 Discovery T1046 Network Service Discovery Both Advanced Port Scanner and NetScan have been used to discover local network infrastructure devices and services running on remote hosts.
sentence.3117: Active Directory queries for remote systems have been performed by ADFind.
sentence.3118: T1057 Process Discovery Process Explorer, Process Monitor and PCHunter have been utilized to discover any anti-malware or monitoring software and terminate it.
sentence.3119: T1082 System Information Discovery LockBit 2.0 enumerates system information such as hostname, shares, and domain information.
sentence.3120: T1614 System Location Discovery Attempts to check the language settings.
sentence.3122: Remote Services Although Cobalt Strike has many capabilities beneficial to threat actors in ransomware attacks, it was mainly seen in LockBit 2.0 investigations acting as a command and control beacon, a method of lateral movement and a tool for downloading/executing files.
sentence.3123: T1021.002 Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares LockBit 2.0 has been known to self-propagate via SMB.
sentence.3124: TA0010 Exfiltration T1030 Data Transfer Size Limits In some cases, LockBit 2.0 will limit the data transfer sizes to fly under the radar of any monitoring services a client may have set up.
sentence.3125: T1041 Exfiltration over C2 Channel MEGASync is the leading way for LockBit 2.0 affiliates to exfiltrate data from clients with it being occasionally replaced by RClone. TA0011 Command and Control T1219
sentence.3126: Remote Access Software AnyDesk has been the most common legitimate desktop software used to establish an interactive command and control channel, with ConnectWise seen slightly less frequently.
sentence.3127: TA0040 Impact T1486 Data Encrypted for Impact LockBit 2.0 is known for its extortion tactics, encrypting devices and demanding a ransom.
sentence.3128: T1489 Service Stop During the defense evasion phase, anti-malware and monitoring software is often disabled.
sentence.3129: Firewall rules have occasionally been seen being disabled as well.
sentence.3130: LockBit 2.0 Technical Details LockBit 2.0 was developed using the Assembly and Origin C programming languages and leverages advanced encryption standard (AES) and elliptic-curve cryptography (ECC) algorithms to encrypt victim data.
sentence.3131: It can affect both Windows and Linux OS, as the operator released a Linux version of LockBit 2.0 to target VMware ESXi hypervisor systems in October 2021, coded exclusively in the C programming language.
sentence.3132: The LockBit group claimed that LockBit 2.0 is “the fastest encryption software all over the world” and provided a comparative table showing the encryption speed of various ransomware samples.
sentence.3136: LockBit 2.0 also contains a self-spreading feature, clears logs and can print the ransom note on network printers until the paper runs out.
sentence.3137: A management panel that affiliates can use to manage victims and affiliate accounts, generate new ransomware builds and generate the decryptor if the demanded ransom is paid also exists.
sentence.3141: LockBit 2.0 operators also released an information-stealer dubbed StealBit, which was developed to support affiliates of the LockBit 2.0 RaaS when exfiltrating data from breached companies.
sentence.3142: StealBit contains the following capabilities: Operates as a file grabber and dumps/uploads victim data to the LockBit victim-shaming site.
sentence.3143: No reliance on third-party cloud file-sharing services, where data can be easily removed if the victim submitted a complaint.
sentence.3144: The download speed is limited only by internet connection bandwidth, so it is possible to clone folders from corporate networks and upload them to the LockBit victim shaming blog quickly.
sentence.3145: The operator of LockBit 2.0 has provided a comparative table speed showing the information stealer compared to other tools. Figure 10.
sentence.3146: LockBit 2.0 download speed, according to LockBit 2.0 operator.
sentence.3147: LockBit 3.0 There was a bug that existed in LockBit 2.0 that allowed researchers to revert the encryption process on an MSSQL database.
sentence.3148: After the bug’s disclosure, LockBit forum members discussed how the bug will not exist in LockBit’s next iteration.
sentence.3149: Moreover, on March 17, LockBit forum members mentioned the release of LockBit’s next version in one or two weeks.
sentence.3150: On March 25, VX underground posted a tweet with details of this new version, dubbed LockBit Black. Figure 11.
sentence.3151: LockBit Black post-infection desktop wallpaper (Source: VX-underground).Courses of Action Several adversarial techniques were observed in this activity and the following measures are suggested within Palo Alto Networks products and services to ensure mitigation of threats related to LockBit 2.0 ransomware, as well as other malware using similar techniques: Product / Service Course of Action Initial Access, Execution, Persistence, Privilege Escalation, Defense Evasion The courses of action below mitigate the following techniques: Exploit Public-Facing Application
sentence.3152: [T1190], Command and Scripting Interpreter [T1059], Local Account [T1136.001], Web Shell
sentence.3154: [T1068], Indicator Removal on Host [T1070], Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
sentence.3155: [T1140], Disable or Modify Tools [T1562.001], Hidden Window [T1564.003], Valid Accounts

sentence.3175: †These capabilities are part of the NGFW security subscriptions service Note: This is not an all-inclusive list of the protections provided by Palo Alto Networks.
sentence.3176: This is a subset of our current Courses of Action initiative and will be updated as the project progresses.
sentence.3177: Conclusion LockBit 2.0 and its evolution over time is a perfect example to illustrate the persistence, increasing complexity and impact brought by the ransomware landscape as a whole.
sentence.3178: With claims of this RaaS offering the fastest encryption on the ransomware market, coupled with the fact that it has been delivered in high volume by experienced affiliates, this RaaS poses a significant threat.
sentence.3179: LockBit’s continuation with operations and its next iteration coming up on the horizon means that organizations and their security teams need to stay vigilant in the ever-evolving threat landscape.
sentence.3180: Palo Alto Networks detects and prevents LockBit 2.0 ransomware in the following ways: WildFire:
sentence.3181: All known samples are identified as malware.
sentence.3182: Cortex XDR: Identifies indicators associated with LockBit 2.0.
sentence.3183: Anti-Ransomware Module to detect LockBit 2.0 encryption behaviors on Windows.
sentence.3184: Local Analysis detection for LockBit 2.0 binaries on Windows.
sentence.3186: DNS Signatures detect the known C2 domains, which are also categorized as malware in Advanced URL Filtering.
sentence.3187: If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call: North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42) EMEA: +31.20.299.3130 APAC:
sentence.3188: +65.6983.8730 Japan: +81.50.1790.0200 Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance members.
sentence.3189: CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors.
sentence.3190: Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.
sentence.3192: In August 2021, a Russian blogger published a 22-minute interview with an alleged representative of the group behind LockBit 2.0 called “LockBitSupp” on a YouTube channel called “Russian-language open source intelligence (OSINT).”
sentence.3193: The same Russian blogger previously published interviews with a representative of the group behind the REvil ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS), hackers and security experts.
sentence.3194: Some key takeaways from the claims made in the interview were: The LockBit 2.0 threat actor claimed the group’s RaaS was unlikely to be rebranded since the team allegedly was a business that was honest with their customers – suggesting a supposed contrast between LockBit 2.0 and Avaddon, DarkSide and REvil affiliates.
sentence.3195: The LockBit 2.0 ransomware disregarded keyboard layout, but it allegedly would not run on a host where the system language was set to any of the languages spoken in the Commonwealth of Independent States region.
sentence.3196: The group did not devise attacks on companies of their choice; they simply worked with initial access to any corporate network they obtained elsewhere, since this was more profitable and saved time.
sentence.3197: The team selected targets for ransomware attacks based on the company’s finances — the bigger, the better.
sentence.3198: The location also did not matter.
sentence.3199: However, team members allegedly did not attack healthcare facilities, social services, educational institutions and charitable organizations or any other organization that “contributed to the survival of the human race.”
sentence.3200: [Note that Unit 42 case data does include indications that threat actors using LockBit 2.0 have targeted healthcare organizations at times.]
sentence.3201: The threat actor claimed that the largest number of victims who paid ransom were company representatives who did not care about creating backup copies and did not protect their sensitive data.
sentence.3202: According to the threat actor’s claims, companies that violated regulations about collecting and handling customer or user personal information were among those eager to pay.
sentence.3203: The threat actor claimed that there generally were only a few companies who refused to pay ransom on principle, while most of the victims evaluated profit and loss to decide whether or not to pay a ransom.
sentence.3204: LockBit 2.0 operators allegedly almost always offered discounts to their victims since the goal was to streamline attacks.
sentence.3205: The threat actor claimed that the COVID-19 pandemic facilitated ransomware attacks significantly, saying it was easy to compromise home computers of employees who work remotely and use them as a springboard to access other networked systems.
sentence.3206: Companies in Europe and the U.S. were hit with ransomware much more often than companies based in other countries allegedly because of high profit and insurance and not because of language barriers.
sentence.3207: Ransomware operators usually recruit negotiators, who coerce victims to pay ransom, since professional penetration testers allegedly lack the time for chatter.

sentence.3210: title: SOC Team Essentials | How to Investigate and Track the 8220 Gang Cloud Threat url: https://www.sentinelone.com/blog/soc-team-essentials-how-to-investigate-and-track-the-8220-gang-cloud-threat/ 8220 Gang is a low-skill crimeware actor known for infecting cloud hosts through n-day vulnerabilities and remote access brute forcing.
sentence.3211: We have previously detailed how 8220 expanded its botnet and rotated its infrastructure.
sentence.3212: Since our last write up in October, the group has again switched to new infrastructure and samples, providing us with an opportunity to share an educational walkthrough of the process of investigating cybercrime activity that may be useful to new or lesser experienced SOC teams, analysts and researchers.
sentence.3213: In this post, we use 8220 Gang activity as a lens through which to explain the process of investigating a threat, researching the threat activity as a whole, and gaining a perspective into attacker objectives, ultimately concluding with a wider understanding of related threat intelligence.
sentence.3214: Refresher on 8220 Gang 8220 Gang (pronounced eighty-two twenty), also known as 8220 Mining Group, was first publicly reported by Talos in 2018.
sentence.3215: Victims of 8220 Gang are typically, but not exclusively, users of cloud networks operating vulnerable and misconfigured Linux applications and services.
sentence.3216: Attacks make use of SSH brute forcing post-infection to automate local and global spreading attempts.
sentence.3217: Victims using cloud infrastructure (AWS, Azure, GCP, Aliyun, QCloud) are often infected via publicly accessible hosts running Docker, Confluence, Apache WebLogic, and Redis.
sentence.3218: Victims are not targeted geographically but simply identified by their internet accessibility.
sentence.3219: Initial Discovery Our walkthrough starts with the initial discovery of an interesting script found on a compromised AWS machine with publicly available SSH service secured with weak credentials.
sentence.3220: For readers not running a honeypot, this initial discovery could have also been observed in the monitoring of new files uploaded to file scanning services like VirusTotal or MalShare.
sentence.3221: For those looking to monitor this group, international SSH honeypots plus VirusTotal YARA rules offer a reliable method of catching new activity as it occurs.
sentence.3222: The script in question has the SHA1 a9da0947243333d95f84f6a0e37b9fc29b2fb054. 8220 Infection Script Snippet We can see it is quite simple in design and built around the process of downloading and setting persistence of some other file.
sentence.3223: With a few string pivots inside VT, or even a few Google searches, we can quickly discover the core functionality of the script has been widely reported on as it has been reused by many amateur cryptocurrency mining groups and opportunistic profit-seeking attackers.
sentence.3224: Pivoting on part of the script’s content in VirusTotal Intelligence One example of such reporting is our July 2022 post on 8220 Gang expanding their botnet to roughly 30,000 hosts.
sentence.3225: However, this time the attacker-specific infrastructure is different, and we have not determined if it has delivered similar malware.
sentence.3226: Remember, this “infection script” is used by many attackers, and it alone is a very weak source of attribution. 8220 Infection Script Analysis The script goes through a set of instructions, often at multiple levels of encoded commands, aimed at the delivery of setting persistence on the victim machine by downloading itself from malicious servers.
sentence.3227: The multiple levels of Base64 encoding attempt to hide the fact that it is also downloading a specific payload as well.
sentence.3228: This is first observed under the createservices function.
sentence.3229: Infection Script createservices Function One difference that’s quickly apparent to past reporting on the script is that the attacker began adding the lwp-download command as a failover for wget and curl to enable downloading commands.
sentence.3230: We initially observed this activity on January 6th, and since then the actor has continued to standardize it in their infection scripts today.
sentence.3231: Sysdig also noted this activity in a recent blog.
sentence.3232: Infection Script use of lwp-download The key take away from analyzing these infection scripts is noting unique additions, like lwp–download, combined with the destination of download requests.
sentence.3233: By clustering infection scripts based on function names and order, if the functions are called, and what infrastructure is associated, we can weed out the non-8220 Gang samples.
sentence.3234: Additionally, we can link this further based on the encoding quantity and repetition to past 8220 Gang samples.
sentence.3235: For example, in our infection scripts createservices makes use of three base64 encoded echo commands.
sentence.3236: The first command can be decoded into a new script which pings associated attacker infrastructure and then starts a “payload” command. Infection Script’s encoded payload
sentence.3237: The payload contains two additional base64 encoded scripts to set permissions, download, and configure miner and IRC bot infections.
sentence.3239: Post-Infection Activity & Sample Pivots The post infection activity for this and other recent 8220 infection scripts evolve slightly, but generally proceed with infecting the victim with an updated PwnRig cryptocurrency miner and IRC bot.
sentence.3240: In the infection scripts we observed in this campaign, the group continued to use old bash IRC bot “Tsunami”.
sentence.3241: The sample delivered remains unchanged; however, the network it communicates with evolves over campaigns.
sentence.3242: The infection script here delivered 472548a4b8295182f6ba8641d74725c2250b7243 – the Tsunami sample.
sentence.3243: More useful for tracking 8220 Gang are the samples of PwnRig – the custom version of the open source XMRig cryptocurrency miner – that they drop.
sentence.3244: In this campaign, the script downloads the UPX packed sample 38be55f1fc4ce1cb5438236abc5077019e5e1cdf, which unpacks to 332485bd460f55117a254f8164736b90d74aa9f6.
sentence.3245: A characteristic of 8220 Gang is their repeated use of fake miner pool domains themed around the FBI.
sentence.3246: Here, we see this theme again through the use of the malicious domain fbi.su1001-2[.]top.
sentence.3247: Infrastructure Analysis Tracking 8220 Gang is aided somewhat by their failures in infrastructure OPSEC.
sentence.3248: Since the beginning of what the industry calls “8220 Gang” the primary method of attribution has been reused infrastructure and identification of newly associated infrastructure.
sentence.3249: While this technique alone does not link the actor with certainty, it remains reliable when combined with the previously noted linkability around malware samples delivered.
sentence.3250: During our initial investigation in January, the group was using 185.106.94[.]146, and dw.bpdeliver[.]ru for malware download location post-infection such as in their infection script.
sentence.3251: Anyone looking into this group should pivot on all subdomains associated with the actor-controlled domain, in addition to all DNS history of malicious IPs to identify a wider set of the malicious activity.
sentence.3252: For example, the recent dw.bpdeliver[.]ru host resolved to 79.137.203[.]156 during the initial deployment of the script.
sentence.3253: More activity of 8220 Gang scripts can be found calling directly to this IP rather than the domain.
sentence.3254: The same goes for 185.106.94[.]146, which is called by IP in the script, and which at the time resolved to jira.letmaker.top, a widely reported known 8220 Gang domain.
sentence.3255: Overall, the group is clumsy and unsophisticated in their infrastructure management, providing a good opportunity for those willing to track the mess or cut their teeth in threat actor investigation.
sentence.3256: Our graphic from a previous campaign explains the overlap, which can still be found in this most recent activity.
sentence.3257: Visual Context of 8220 Gang Infrastructure Roles Conclusion Tracking and researching 8220 Gang, which has exhibited a lack of operational security, requires a simple understanding of their use of malicious scripts, malware samples, and malicious infrastructure.
sentence.3258: A successful approach to tracking this group can involve monitoring and analyzing malware samples, identifying patterns in their malicious scripts, and mapping out their infrastructure. Indicators of Compromise Indicator Description a9da0947243333d95f84f6a0e37b9fc29b2fb054 8220 Gang Install Script 472548a4b8295182f6ba8641d74725c2250b7243 8220 Gang Bashirc.x86_64 – PackedOld version, “Tsunami” 38be55f1fc4ce1cb5438236abc5077019e5e1cdf 8220 Gang X86_64 – Packed MinerUses fbi.su1001-2[.]top 332485bd460f55117a254f8164736b90d74aa9f6 e2c3e.
sentence.3259: Unpacked, PwnRig Miner 194.38.23.170 8220 Gang Infrastructure – Shared jira.letmaker.top 8220 Gang Infrastructure – Reused 185.106.94.146 8220 Gang Infrastructure dw.bpdeliver.ru 8220 Gang Infrastructure – Recent fbi.su1001-2.top 8220 Gang Infrastructure – Recent 79.137.203.156 8220 Gang Infrastructure
sentence.3260: title: Fantasy – a new Agrius wiper deployed through a supply‑chain attack url: https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/12/07/fantasy-new-agrius-wiper-supply-chain-attack/ ESET researchers analyzed a supply-chain attack abusing an Israeli software developer to deploy Fantasy, Agrius’s new wiper, with victims including the diamond industry ESET researchers discovered a new wiper and its execution tool, both attributed to the Agrius APT group, while analyzing a supply-chain attack abusing an Israeli software developer.
sentence.3261: The group is known for its destructive operations.
sentence.3262: In February 2022, Agrius began targeting Israeli HR and IT consulting firms, and users of an Israeli software suite used in the diamond industry.
sentence.3263: We believe that Agrius operators conducted a supply-chain attack abusing the Israeli software developer to deploy their new wiper, Fantasy, and a new lateral movement and Fantasy execution tool, Sandals.
sentence.3264: The Fantasy wiper is built on the foundations of the previously reported Apostle wiper but does not attempt to masquerade as ransomware, as Apostle originally did.
sentence.3265: Instead, it goes right to work wiping data.
sentence.3266: Victims were observed in South Africa – where reconnaissance began several weeks before Fantasy was deployed – Israel, and Hong Kong.
sentence.3267: Key points of this blogpost: Agrius conducted a supply-chain attack abusing an Israeli software suite used in the diamond industry.
sentence.3268: The group then deployed a new wiper we named Fantasy.
sentence.3269: Most of its code base comes from Apostle, Agrius’s previous wiper.
sentence.3270: Along with Fantasy, Agrius also deployed a new lateral movement and Fantasy execution tool that we have named Sandals.
sentence.3271: Victims include Israeli HR firms, IT consulting companies, and a diamond wholesaler; a South African organization working in the diamond industry; and a jeweler in Hong Kong.
sentence.3272: Group overview Agrius is a newer Iran-aligned group targeting victims in Israel and the United Arab Emirates since 2020.
sentence.3273: The group initially deployed a wiper, Apostle, disguised as ransomware, but later modified Apostle into fully fledged ransomware.
sentence.3274: Agrius exploits known vulnerabilities in internet-facing applications to install webshells, then conducts internal reconnaissance before moving laterally and then deploying its malicious payloads.
sentence.3275: Campaign overview On February 20th, 2022 at an organization in the diamond industry in South Africa, Agrius deployed credential harvesting tools, probably in preparation for this campaign.
sentence.3276: Then, on March 12th, 2022, Agrius launched the wiping attack by deploying Fantasy and Sandals, first to the victim in South Africa and then to victims in Israel and lastly to a victim in Hong Kong.
sentence.3277: Victims in Israel include an IT support services company, a diamond wholesaler, and an HR consulting firm.
sentence.3278: South African victims are from a single organization in the diamond industry, with the Hong Kong victim being a jeweler.
sentence.3281: The campaign lasted less than three hours and within that timeframe ESET customers were already protected with detections identifying Fantasy as a wiper, and blocking its execution.
sentence.3282: We observed the software developer pushing out clean updates within a matter of hours of the attack.
sentence.3283: We reached out to the software developer to notify them about a potential compromise, but our enquiries went unanswered.
sentence.3284: Preparing for departure The first tools deployed by Agrius operators to victim systems, through means unknown, were: MiniDump, “a C# implementation of mimikatz/pypykatz minidump functionality to get credentials from LSASS dumps” SecretsDump, a Python script that “performs various techniques to dump hashes from [a] remote machine without executing any agent there” Host2IP, a custom C#/.NET tool that resolves a hostname to an IP address.
sentence.3285: Usernames, passwords, and hostnames collected by these tools are required for Sandals to successfully spread and execute the Fantasy wiper.
sentence.3286: Agrius operators deployed MiniDump and SecretsDump to this campaign’s first victim on February 20th, 2022, but waited until March 12th, 2022 to deploy Host2IP, Fantasy, and Sandals (consecutively).
sentence.3288: Sandals is a 32-bit Windows executable written in C#/.NET.
sentence.3289: We chose the name because Sandals is an anagram of some of the command line arguments it accepts.
sentence.3290: It is used to connect to systems in the same network via SMB, to write a batch file to disk that executes the Fantasy wiper, and then run that batch file via PsExec with this command line string:
sentence.3293: -s “C:\<path>\<GUID>.bat” The PsExec options have the following meanings: -d – Don’t wait for process to terminate (non-interactive).
sentence.3294: /accepteula – Suppress display of the license dialog.
sentence.3296: Run the remote process in the SYSTEM account.
sentence.3297: Sandals does not write the Fantasy wiper to remote systems.
sentence.3298: We believe that the Fantasy wiper is deployed via a supply-chain attack using the software developer’s software update mechanism.
sentence.3299: This assessment is based on several factors: all victims were customers of the affected software developer; the Fantasy wiper was named in a similar fashion to legitimate versions of the software; all victims executed the Fantasy wiper within a 2.5 hour timeframe, where victims in South Africa were targeted first, then victims in Israel, and finally victims in Hong Kong (we attribute the delay in targeting to time zone differences and a hardcoded check-in time within the legitimate software); and, lastly, the Fantasy wiper was written to, and executed from, %SYSTEM%\Windows\Temp, the default temp directory for Windows systems.
sentence.3300: Additionally, we believe the victims were already using PsExec, and Agrius operators chose to use PsExec to blend into typical administrative activity on the victims’ machines, and for ease of batch file execution.
sentence.3301: Table 1 lists the command line arguments accepted by Sandals.
sentence.3303: Sandals arguments and their descriptions ArgumentDescriptionRequired -f
sentence.3305: A path and filename to a file that contains a list of hostnames that should be targeted.
sentence.3307: The username that will be used to log into the remote hostname(s) in argument -f.
sentence.3308: Yes -p <password>The username that will be used to log into the remote hostname(s) in argument -f.
sentence.3309: Yes -l <filepath>The path and filename of the Fantasy wiper on the remote system that will be executed by the batch file created by Sandals.
sentence.3311: The location to which Sandals will write the batch file on the remote system.
sentence.3315: The amount of time, in seconds, that Sandals will sleep between writing the batch file to disk and executing.
sentence.3317: No -a file <filepath> or-a random or-a rsaIf -a is followed by the word file and a path and filename, Sandals uses the encryption key in the supplied file.
sentence.3318: If -a is followed by rsa or random, Sandals uses the RSACryptoServiceProvider class to generate a public-private key pair with a key size of 2,048.
sentence.3319: No -dn <devicename>Specifies which drive to connect with on a remote system over SMB.
sentence.3320: Default is C:.No -ps <filepath>Location of PsExec on disk.
sentence.3321: Default is psexec.exe in the current working directory.
sentence.3322: No -raIf -ra is supplied at runtime, it sets the variable flag to True (initially set to False).
sentence.3323: If flag=True, Sandals deletes all files written to disk in the current working directory.
sentence.3324: If flag=False, Sandals skips the file cleanup step.
sentence.3325: No The batch file written to disk by Sandals is named <GUID>.bat, where the filename is the output of the Guid.
sentence.3327: An example of a Sandals batch file is shown in Figure 2.
sentence.3329: Sandals batch file (top, in red) and the decoded command line parameter (bottom, in blue)
sentence.3330: The base64 string that follows fantasy35.exe is likely a relic of the execution requirements of Apostle (more details in the Attribution to Agrius section).
sentence.3331: However, the Fantasy wiper only looks for an argument of 411 and ignores all other runtime input (see the next section for more information).
sentence.3332: Fantasy wiper The Fantasy wiper is also a 32-bit Windows executable written in C#/.NET, so named for its filenames: fantasy45.exe and fantasy35.exe, respectively.
sentence.3333: Figure 3 depicts the execution flow of the Fantasy wiper.
sentence.3335: Fantasy wiper execution flow Initially, Fantasy creates a mutex to ensure that only one instance is running.
sentence.3336: It collects a list of fixed drives but excludes the drive where the %WINDOWS% directory exists.
sentence.3337: Then it enters a for loop iterating over the drive list to build a recursive directory listing, and uses the RNGCryptoServiceProvider.
sentence.3338: GetBytes method to create a cryptographically strong sequence of random values in a 4096-byte array.
sentence.3339: If a runtime argument of 411 is supplied to the wiper, the for loop overwrites the contents of every file with the aforementioned byte array using a nested while loop.
sentence.3340: Otherwise, the for loop only overwrites files with a file extension listed in the Appendix.
sentence.3341: Fantasy then assigns a specific timestamp (2037-01-01 00:00:00) to these file timestamp properties: CreationTime LastAccessTime LastWriteTime CreationTimeUtc SetLastAccessTimeUtc LastWriteTimeUtc and then deletes the file.
sentence.3342: This is presumably done to make recovery and forensic analysis more difficult.
sentence.3343: During the for loop, the Fantasy wiper counts errors within the current directory when attempting to overwrite files.
sentence.3344: If the number of errors exceeds 50, it writes a batch file, %WINDOWS%\Temp\<GUID>.bat, that deletes the directory with the files causing the errors, and then self-deletes.
sentence.3345: File wiping then resumes in the next directory in the target list.
sentence.3346: Once the for loop completes, the Fantasy wiper creates a batch file in %WINDOWS%\Temp called registry.bat.
sentence.3347: The batch file deletes the following registry keys: HKCR\.EXE HKCR\.dll HKCR\* Then it runs the following to attempt to clear file system cache memory:
sentence.3349: Next, the Fantasy wiper clears all Windows event logs and creates another batch file, system.bat, in %WINDOWS%\Temp, that recursively deletes all files on %SYSTEMDRIVE%, attempts to clear file system cache memory, and self-deletes.
sentence.3350: Then Fantasy sleeps for two minutes before overwriting the system’s Master Boot Record.
sentence.3351: Fantasy then writes another batch file, %WINDOWS%\Temp\remover.bat, that deletes the Fantasy wiper from disk and then deletes itself.
sentence.3352: Then Fantasy wiper sleeps for 30 seconds before rebooting the system with reason code SHTDN_REASON_MAJOR_OTHER (0x00000000) — Other issue.
sentence.3353: It is likely that %SYSTEMDRIVE% recovery is possible.
sentence.3354: Victims were observed to be back up and running within a matter of hours.
sentence.3355: Attribution to Agrius Much of the code base from Apostle, initially a wiper masquerading as ransomware then updated to actual ransomware, was directly copied to Fantasy and many other functions in Fantasy were only slightly modified from Apostle, a known Agrius tool.
sentence.3356: However, the overall functionality of Fantasy is that of a wiper without any attempt to masquerade as ransomware.
sentence.3357: Figure 4 shows the file deletion functions in Fantasy and Apostle, respectively.
sentence.3358: There are only a few small tweaks between the original function in Apostle and the Fantasy implementation.
sentence.3360: File deletion functions from the Fantasy wiper (top, in red) and Apostle ransomware (bottom, in green) Figure 4.
sentence.3361: File deletion functions from the Fantasy wiper (top, in red) and Apostle ransomware (bottom, in green) Figure 5 shows that the directory listing function is almost a direct copy, with only the function variables getting a slight tweak between Apostle and Fantasy.
sentence.3363: Directory listing functions from the Fantasy wiper (top, in red) and Apostle ransomware (bottom, in green)
sentence.3364: Finally, the GetSubDirectoryFileListRecursive function in Figure 6 is also almost an exact copy.
sentence.3366: Recursive directory listing functions from the Fantasy wiper (top, in red) and Apostle ransomware (bottom, in green)
sentence.3367: In addition to the code reuse, we can see remnants of the Apostle execution flow in Fantasy.
sentence.3368: In the original analysis of Apostle, SentinelOne notes that “Proper execution of the ransomware version requires supplying it with a base64 encoded argument containing an XML of an ‘RSAParameters’ object.
sentence.3369: This argument is passed on and saved as the Public Key used for the encryption process and is most likely generated on a machine owned by the threat actor.”
sentence.3370: We can see in the batch file in Figure 7, which Sandals creates on remote systems to launch Fantasy, that the same base64-encoded argument containing an XML of an RSAParameters object is passed to Fantasy at runtime.
sentence.3371: Fantasy, however, does not use this runtime argument.
sentence.3373: Sandals passing to Fantasy the same RSAParameters object as was used by Apostle ransomware Conclusion Since its discovery in 2021, Agrius has been solely focused on destructive operations.
sentence.3374: To that end, Agrius operators probably executed a supply-chain attack by targeting an Israeli software company’s software updating mechanisms to deploy Fantasy, its newest wiper, to victims in Israel, Hong Kong, and South Africa.
sentence.3375: Fantasy is similar in many respects to the previous Agrius wiper, Apostle, that initially masqueraded as ransomware before being rewritten to be actual ransomware.
sentence.3376: Fantasy makes no effort to disguise itself as ransomware.
sentence.3377: Agrius operators used a new tool, Sandals, to connect remotely to systems and execute Fantasy.

sentence.3391: APython script that dumps credential hashes.
sentence.3393: XHSandals lateral movement tool and Fantasy spreader.
sentence.3394: MITRE ATT&CK techniques This table was built using version 12 of the MITRE ATT&CK framework.
sentence.3395: TacticIDNameDescription Resource DevelopmentT1587Develop CapabilitiesAgrius builds utility tools to use during an active exploitation process.
sentence.3396: T1587.001Develop Capabilities: MalwareAgrius builds custom malware including wipers (Fantasy) and lateral movement tools (Sandals).
sentence.3397: Initial AccessT1078.002Valid Accounts: Domain AccountsAgrius operators attempted to capture cached credentials and then use them for lateral movement. T1078.003Valid Accounts: Local AccountsAgrius operators attempted to use cached credentials from local accounts to gain initial access to additional systems within an internal network.
sentence.3399: Windows Command ShellFantasy and Sandals both use batch files that run via the Windows command shell. Privilege EscalationT1134Access Token ManipulationFantasy uses the LookupPrivilegeValue and AdjustTokenPrivilege APIs in advapi32.dll to grant its process token the SeShutdownPrivilege to reboot Windows.
sentence.3400: Defense EvasionT1070.006Indicator Removal on Host: TimestompAgrius operators timestomped the compilation timestamps of Fantasy and Sandals.
sentence.3401: Credential AccessT1003OS Credential DumpingAgrius operators used several tools to dump OS credentials for use in lateral movement.
sentence.3402: DiscoveryT1135Network Share DiscoveryAgrius operators used cached credentials to check for access to other systems within an internal network.
sentence.3403: Lateral MovementT1021.002Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin SharesAgrius operators used cached credentials to connect over SMB to systems within an exploited internal network.
sentence.3404: T1570Lateral Tool TransferAgrius operators used Sandals to push batch files over SMB to other systems within an internal network.
sentence.3405: ImpactT1485Data DestructionThe Fantasy wiper overwrites data in files and then deletes the files.
sentence.3406: T1561.002Disk WipeFantasy wipes the MBR of the Windows drive and attempts to wipe the OS partition.
sentence.3407: T1561.001Disk Wipe: Disk Content WipeFantasy wipes all disk contents from non-Windows drives that are fixed drives.
sentence.3408: T1529System Shutdown/RebootFantasy reboots the system after completing its disk and data wiping payloads.
